title: boris lots to offer young people
story: As a spec-free, state-educated young woman, my voting intentions tend to be greeted with a mixture of shock and resentment. By not supporting Jeremy Corbyn and his Communist buddies, I am - I am told - an “age traitor”. Boris is for boomers, the thinking goes, and Corbyn is for us.But scratch the surface and you’ll find that the Prime Minister - a man who made his name as mayor of London - has rather a lot to offer us young folk. And Jeremy Corbyn - a Marxist straight from the s- might just make  our lives a hell of a lot worse.Take, for example, the issue the vast majority of young people say matters to them most: housing.If you’re a young private renter, Corbyn’s radical plan to crackdown on “dodgy” landlords sounds really rather good.But there’s a serious catch. If landlords could be forced by the government to sell their homes to tenants at a price dictated by the Government, the buy-to-let market would collapse. And fast.In a few pockets of the country, where housing supply is plentul, that would be great. With landlords out of the picture, those desperate to get on the property ladder might stand a chance.In most of Britain, though, the picture wouldn’t be so rosy. Where available housing is precious and most people can’t afford to get on the housing ladderprivate renting is a blessing. And a collapse in the buy-to-let market would hike the price of it.So under Corbyn’s “fairer Britain”, those right at the start of their careers would soon be priced out of metropolitan areas.Then take university fees. Again, the idea of “free uni” sounds very tempting indeed. But under Corbyn’s regime, university tuition wouldn’t suddenly become free. It would just be paid for by the tax-payer instead of the student.What does that mean in practice  Well, it means that the  per cent of young people who opt to get a job end up at  would end up massively subsidising the  per cent who choose to enjoy three years of student le. I loved my time at uni, but I don’t see why my  year old cousin - who’s been working his socks off in the navy for three years - should be forced to pay for it.And evenyou are a student or planning to go to university, Corbyn won’t help you in any real sense. If students don’t contribute to their own education, universities suddenly have a lot less money. Which means they can’t admit as many teenagers.In Scotland, for example, where tuition has been “free” for years, fewer and fewer young people are going to university. And because the middle classes know how to game the system, it tends to be disadvantaged kids who get let down.Andyou work for yourself, which around % of Generation Z would like to do, Labour’s radical tax plan certainly isn’t for you.Even though Jeremy Corbyn has promised that only the richest five per cent of workers will face higher bills, new analysis shows that self-employed workers earning much less could be £, a year worse off under the new rules. And sole traders - ie. young, ambitious entrepreneurs who pay themselves lower salaries in order to invest in their businesses - would suffer the most.Boris Johnson might not be a hit at Glastonbury. But like a true One Nation Conservative, he believes in opportunity. And his pragmatic schemes, like % deposit mortgages, would give hard working young people a proper leg up in le.I don’t hunt, I don’t shoot, and I wouldn’t be seen dead in tweed. But I believe that a country can only succeed when ambitious young people are encouraged by the state to spread their wings and fly. title: election jeremy corbyn nightmare rod liddle
story: I dream I’ve just woken up and I look at the clock. It says “Friday th”. Then I hear a horrible cackling — and, OMG, it’s Diane Abbott standing by my bed, her face split open with mirth.“We’re in charge now!” she shrieks: “Ha ha ha ha ha.” And then the rest of the ghouls appear.Magic Grandpa Jeremy Corbyn, smirking through his beard, wearing his Lenin hat. Jo Swinson of the Lib Dems like a Girl Guide Leader from Hades. And then — grinning like Janette Krankie on acid — Nicola Sturgeon of the SNP.I try to hide under the covers but Diane pulls them back. “We’re in charge now,” she repeats. “And first we’re going to wreck Brexit. And then we’re going to wreck the country. Ha ha ha ha.”Friday, December  is the day we find out who will be ruling us for the next five years. And my nightmare could quite possibly come true.I’ve been saying for ages that the idiotic Corbyn could win this election — without actually winning any more seats.It is an incredibly precarious position for Boris Johnson and the Conservatives — and thus for Brexit.The polls seem to be tightening. The Conservatives haven’t run a terribly good campaign, it’s true.All it needs is another drop in the Tory lead of one per cent and we would be heading for a hung Parliament.That almost certainly means a government led by Corbyn, with support from the Lib Dems and the SNP. It would definitely mean an end for Brexit.The democratic decision we took three years ago would be forgotten. At best there would be ANOTHER referendum.Almost certainly rigged by Labour and the Lib Dems to ensure that, this time, the right side won, ie, their side.They have no respect whatsoever for that democratic mandate. They are very clear about that. But there will be even worse to come.Labour will usher in a ruinous economic programme which the country cannot possibly afford.Our entrepreneurs will flee the country. We’ll be back in huge debt once again. Spending on stuff we cannot afford.Labour plans to spend TWENTY EIGHT times as much money as the ConservativesWorst of all, we will be led by a halfwit who supports every enemy known to this country.You name a terrorist cell or a vile, authoritarian country and mad old Jezza will at some point have offered it support.From the IRA to the genocidal Islamists Hamas, from Cuba to Iran.The brilliant website Guido Fawkes has detailed all the times Corbyn has stuck up for terrorists or horrible totalitarian governments. Gawd help us, the list is almost endless.This is a bloke who has said he wishes Nato didn’t exist. That’s the military alliance which has kept peace for  years!But don’t take my word for it. Just this week yet another Labour MP was caught moaning about how truly bloody awful Corbyn was.Jonathan Ashworth said voters were turned off by the man and that the prospects for Labour were “dire”.He added: “I’m helping colleagues, banging on about the NHS for them, but it’s awful for them, and it’s the combination of Corbyn and Brexit . . . outside of the city seats . . . it’s abysmal out there . . . they can’t stand Corbyn and they think Labour’s blocked Brexit.”That’s not “Tory lies”, as the lefties always say when someone takes a pop at the old scrote.That’s a member of his own front-bench team. But then a good two thirds of Labour MPs can’t stand Corbyn and think he would be awful for this country.As Boris Johnson said, Ashworth was only saying what hundreds of Labour candidates and millions of voters were thinking.You wonder why some of those candidates don’t have the courage of their convictions and stand down.In fact, plenty have already done so. Ivan Lewis, for example, who has urged everybody to vote Conservative.Then there was John Woodcock and Ian Austin. Both former Labour MPs, moderates. They even made placards telling people to vote Tory.More MPs left Labour long ago — such as Chuka Umunna, who is now standing as a Liberal Democrat, and Brexiteer Kate Hoey can’t bring herself to support the party she served for  years.The man and his retinue of Trots — John McDonnell, Rebecca Long-Bailey , the ghastly Diane Abbott — are a laughing stock. Except I don’t find very much to laugh about, to tell you the truth.And along with Labour and the Lib Dems will come more stupid, socially isive identity politics. The whole country ided up into competing victimhoods.Gay, transgender, black, Asian. Asthese were the things which define us as human beings.But then that’s the infantile and damaging way the Left sees the world.Given all this, you might think it incredible that Corbyn could ever get the keys to No Downing Street. So many people despise the bloke.And that’s before we factor in his repellent anti-Semitism .And you might look at the polls and think — well, the Tories still have a decent lead. Nothing much to worry about.It won’t be Friday th or Nightmare On Abbott Street. It might well be Groundhog Day, but that’s preferable. But this is the big problem for BoJo and his Conservative team. Complacency. The suspicion on the part of the electorate that Corbyn could never actually win. When he could win all too easily — and don’t forget, the opinion polls are very often wrong.The other problem for the Tories is, of course, the Brexit Party. They are still fielding candidates in seats up and down the country — seats which the Tories need to win in order to form a government.Some senior figures in the Brexit Party have already said they would be far better off backing the Tories in order to get Brexit done.But Brexit Party boss Nigel Farage will not listen to them.So we have the terrible situation where people might vote for the Brexit Party in order to make sure we leave the European Union — but in doing so actually STOP Brexit from occurring.Becausethe Brexit Party takes lots of votes from the Tories, that lets in Labour and the Lib Dems through the back door. And the result  No Brexit.It’s in those seats in the North and Midlands where the Conservatives are most vulnerable to a high Brexit Party vote.This is a crucial election. Not just for Brexit, but for Britain’s future.That means a vote for the Conservatives, no matter how much that sticks in the craw.I’ve mentioned before that the only time I voted Tory I felt pretty glum afterwards.But this time there really is no alternative except in a tiny handful of seats where the Tories cannot possibly win.Once this election is out of the way, we need a new party to provide opposition to the Tories.A party that will replace Labour. For me, that’s the Social Democrats. But we’re not at that stage yet.For now it’s a case of walking to the polling booth, holding your nose and voting Blue.You decide our government. You may have your doubts about our democracy — I don’t blame you! You may feel uneasy voting Tory — don’t blame you for that, either.But you hold the destiny of our country in your hands.Indeed, when you put that cross in a box, you ARE the government. The person who decides what is best for our country.So make your vote count, please — and banish those nightmares for ever. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mh370 air traffic controllers mystery never solved
story: The packed passenger jet dropped off the radar screens of flight monitors in Malaysia just five seconds after it crossed into Vietnamese airspace.But the controller monitoring its progress in Kuala Lumpur was dealing with other traffic on his screen and didn’t notice it had vanished.Its been reported by the Atlantic that when he finally did, he assumed that it was now in the hands of his counterparts in Ho Chi Minh.However, Vietnamese controllers saw the Boeing  - which vanished with  on board - cross into their airspace and then also disappear.They then apparently misunderstood rules which meant they were supposed to inform Malaysia immediatelya plane did not show up.They tried repeatedly to contact the flight crww of the aircraft - which is believed to have crashed into the ocean - but to no avail.By the time they finally picked up the phone to inform Kuala Lumpur,  minutes had passed since its sudden disappearance.What ensued was an exercise in confusion and incompetence full of blunders, say those close to the long-running investigationKuala Lumpur’s Aeronautical Rescue Coordination Centre should have been notied within an hour of the disappearance, they say.Malaysia Airlines Flight MH took off from Kuala Lumpur and was heading to Beijing with  people on board.Passengers included Chinese calligraphers, a couple on their way home to their young sons after a long-delayed honeymoon and a construction worker who hadnt been home in a year.But at .am on March , , Malaysia Airlines lost contact with MH close to Phuket island in the Strait of Malacca.Before that, Malaysian authorities believe the last words heard from the plane, from either the pilot or co-pilot, was Good night Malaysian three seven zero.Satellite pings from the aircraft suggest it continued flying for around seven hours when the fuel would have run out.Experts have calculated the most likely crash site around , miles west of Perth, Australia.But a huge search of the seabed failed to find any wreckage - and there are a number of alternative theories as to its fate.However, it eventually took more than four hours to alert rescuers - which means it is virtually impossible to pinpoint where and when it went down.Five pieces, thought to be from the Malaysia Airlines plane, later washed up in Madagascar - more than , miles from Vietnam.Aviation expert Victor Iannello believes one fragment, which appears to be from the interior floorboard, is consistent with a “high-speed impact.More than  bits of aircraft debris have so far been collected from ious places around the world over the past five years.However, only three wing fragments that washed up along the Indian Ocean have been confirmed to be from the missing flight.Its been reported earlier this year that the pilot was in control until the very end but made abnormal turns before crashing.French investigators have been given access to a considerable amount of flight data sent during the flight prior to the crash.Official documents lend weight to fears pilot Zaharie Ahmad Shah, , crashed into the sea in a murder-suicide, they were cited as saying.Some feared Russian president Vladimir Putin was involved in the hijacking of MH.US Science writer Jeff Wise claimed Putin spoofed the planes navigation data so it could fly unnoticed into Baikonur Cosmodrome so he could hurt the West.French ex-airline director Marc Dugain accused the US military of shooting down the plane because they feared it had been hijacked.Malaysia police chief Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar suggested the disappearance could have been the result of a suicide.He claimed someone on board could have taken out a large le insurance package before getting on the plane, so they could treat their family or pay back the money they owed.Historian and writer Norman Davies suggested MH could have been remotely hacked and flown to a secret location as a result of sensitive material being carried aboard the jet.Malaysia Airlines found a -inch crack in the fuselage of one of its planes, days before MH disappeared.The Federal Aviation Administration insists it issued a final warning two days before the disappearance.But the Daily Mirror claimed the missing jet did not have the same antenna as the rest of the Boeing s so it did not receive the warning.Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull unexpectedly said it was “very likely that the captain planned this shocking event”.He claimed the pilot wanted to create the worlds greatest mystery.Another theory claimed that he hijacked his own plane in protest of the jailing of then-Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, and as a way to destabilise the corrupt government of Najib Razak.Another seemingly far-fetched idea said the pilot had deliberately crashed the plane to cover his track as he had parachuted out of the plane so he could spend the rest of his le with his girlfriend who was waiting in a boat in the sea.In the wake of the incident, South Korea noted that North Korea nearly took out a Chinese plane which had  passengers on board, on March , .Some fear Pyongyang shot the plane down, but others believe it was hijacked and erted into the communist nation.One theory claims that because many relatives were able to hear a ringing tone for up to four days after the crash so the doomed jet could not have smashed into the Indian Ocean.Nineteen families have all claimed the devices of their loved ones rang for up to four days after the jet went missing.However, wireless analysts claim that phone firms sometimes use a phantom ringing sound when the device is not active, the Daily Star reports.In September , British video producer Ian Wilson claimed to have found the missing aircraft using Google Maps.Despite millions being spent on the search to located the wreckage, the Brit sleuth believes he has found the jet in a mountainous area of the Cambodian jungle.In response, the Chinese government used observation company Space View to focus in on the high-altitude area on the outskirts of Phnom Penh.However, the firm claim there was no sign of any plane, least of all the Malaysian Airlines aircraft which has been missing since March .An MH sleuth has claimed that locals in Cambodia told him they saw a plane believed to be the doomed Malaysia Airlines flight crashing in the jungle.If the jet was flying north then possible locations could stretch as fast as the border between Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan to Thailand.The Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak originally asked the Kazakhstan leader Nursultan Nazarbayev to set up a search operation in the country but this quickly got sidelined as the rescue efforts focused on the Indian Ocean.The doomed flight is said to have mysteriously “flew round in circles” and veered of course shortly before disappearing.Data from British satellites could indicate the plane was oddly circling above the Pacic Ocean in South East Asia in the moments before it vanished.Aviation expert Jeff Wise, author of the Plane That Wasnt There, said data from Inmarsat, may suggest MH was flying bizarrely during its last minutes.Usually a jet will circle at a fixed altitude after being instructed to do so by air traffic control before being allowed to land at an airport.A satellite called F had made contact with the plane in the hours after it went missing via a series of what is technically known as electronic “handshakes”.Mr Wise explained: Just as the motion of a speeding train makes the tone of its whistle go up or down, the relative motion of the satellite and the aeroplane shts the frequency of the radio signals transmitted between them.MH’s disappearance has also given rise to a slew of conspiracy theories - some far more bizarre than others.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lonely pensioner tears christmas tree carol
story: Terrence, , was brought some festive joy at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, by students from Oldham College and BBC Breakfast host Dan Walker.They paid him a Christmas visit after hed said earlier on the show that he struggled with loneliness and didnt have a Christmas tree in his house.Mr Walker surprised Terrence on his doorstep and introduced him to four students from the nearby college — one of whom had brought a Christmas tree.Terrence came to say hello but he started crying as he greeted the well-wishers inidually.After the students finished decorating the tree, Mr Walker took Terrence to his front door where the college choir sang Silent Night, which overwhelmed him.Terrence told BBC Breakfast: What used to happen, I used to go round to my mothers on Christmas Day because I always cooked a meal for her here.I always took the thing round to her, and I used to buy her little bits all the time, like cigarettes and all this sort of stuff, and I used to parcel them all up at Christmas and put them in a pillow case and take them round to her.One day, Ill never forger her saying to me, she said, Do you know, without you, bringing me my presents at Christmas, I wouldnt have any presents would I I often think about that now. People on their own now dont get any presents from people.He added that this year he was going to Christamas dinner with Nancy, a -year-old woman with dementia whom he met through his work with Age UK Oldham.Terrence appeared on BBC Breakfast earlier in the day to talk about his depression and loneliness — but how his work with the charity was helping.he said: I always think with anything, unless youve actually been there you dont know what it was like.I ddint know what it was like to have depression until I got it.Last week, Age UK revealed that millions of elderly people in Britain might not like Christmas because they see it as the loneliest time of the year.The charitys figures suggested more than three million older people may not be looking forward to the festive season, with roughly , spending Christmas alone.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vet mistakenly euthanized dachshund
story: Andrea Martinez found her dachshund puppy, Ziggy, vomiting on Saturday night and she rushed him to an animal hospital in Utah.During Ziggys surgery, it became apparent the puppy would need a more complicated and expensive procedure.A hospital staffer erroneously dialed the owner of a dferent dog, also named Ziggy, explained the situation and asked whether she would like to proceed with the surgery, or put the pooch down.The other owner opted to have the pet euthanized, not knowing that the dog in question was not hers.At .am on Monday, Martinez got a call telling her Ziggy had died.She wrote on Facebook: They let a stranger decide my dogs [sic] fate.They robbed me the choice of saying at-least We tried.I feel so sick and cant stop crying.Martinez said Ziggy followed her everywhere, cuddled with her every night and helped with her anxiety, and he was also her young daughters best friend.She said: How do you tell a -year-old her best friend died and we didnt have a choice to try everything to stop him from dying.This whole thing seriously makes me so sick to my stomach.Martinez said the vet has apologised and waived Ziggys hospital bill.The vet also provided an urn for his ashes and a Christmas tree ornament featuring the puppys paw print.On Tuesday, Martinez posted a message on her Facebook page saying she has decided not to pursue legal action against the animal hospital.She said: It was a honest mistake, they owned it, and are taking steps to make things okay.Ziggy was really sick and from the sounds of it, I’m not sure he would’ve even made it after all said and done.I do wish we would’ve had to chance to find out tho but le happens and we have to learn to adjust and learn and grow from it. I will forever miss him but at least I know he’s not in pain anymore.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: But who will be the next person in Number  after today  Will Boris remain or will Corbyn be elected  Heres what the bookies and the latest polls say.Follow our general election  live blog for all the latest news and updatesWere counting down the hours to when Brits take to the polls, so whos got the edge so far The polls continue to give the Tories a nationwide lead but one major new survey has slashed Boris Johnsons lead by more than half.The bombshell YouGov MRP poll for The Times put the Conservatives at a -seat majority with just two days to go until the general election.The poll, which correctly forecast the election results in , has revealed Boris will need every vote at Thursdays ballot.This is despite the projected majority meaning the Tories will have clinched  seats -  more than the general election two years ago when they received .The detailed seat-by-seat analysis means every vote will make all the dference  Brits want to avoid another hung parliament - with just  seats currently in it.Boris has hammered home his warning of a clear and present danger of a Corbyn governmentBrits dont check the Conservative box on their ballot paper.The Tories are concerned a Labour victory is “much closer” than their supporters think due to tactical voting for Remainers.On October , MPs approved the PMs call for an election to be held on December .It was Mr Johnsons fourth attempt to have Parliament agree to an election after the Labour Party blocked the vote three times.Parliament shut down from November .When this happens every seat in the House of Commons becomes vacant with those wishing to remain as MPs having to stand in the forthcoming election.The UK can leave before that dateMr Johnsons deal is passed in Parliament.The Prime Minister had vowed to push for an electionthe EU granted a three-month extension for his Brexit bill.Mr Johnson sent a letter to the EU requesting a delay until January  after he was compelled to do so when the Benn Act was passed MPs on October .On October , the EU granted the UKs request for a flextension until January , .

title: britain one national freedom other brexit paralysis
story: One path leads to British independence under Conservative leader Boris Johnson - but the other path follows a far darker course into chaos under Jeremy Corbyn’s Marxist cult.A Johnson victory should usher in a new age of prosperity and national freedom, while a Corbyn triumph will end in Brexit paralysis and financial bankruptcy.A Tory Government will ensure that Britain remains an advanced western economy, where taxes are kept down and enterprise encouraged, where as a Labour Government will turn our country into a basket case, wrecked by trade union bullying and the confiscation of wealth.Every citizen who genuinely cares about our future and cherishes British values therefore has a duty to vote against Corbyn’s hard-left Labour.In practice, that requires everyone - from Tory Remainers to hard Brexiteers - backing the Tories - because only a vote for Boris Johnson can be guaranteed to prevent a brutal Corbyn regime.A vote for the Liberal Democrats or the Brexit Party is not a wasted vote in this election -its something far more dangerous.It is effectively an act of support for Corbyn, forthere is another hung Parliament he will almost certainly emerge as the new Prime Minister.The same is true of moderate, centrist Labour voters who kid themselves that they can back their local Labour candidate while still hoping to avoid the calamity of a Corbyn Government.This is just irresponsible self-deceit. Every vote for Labour brings the Corbyn revolution a step closer.That catastrophe could easily happen this week.In recent opinion polls, the Tories have maintained a consistent lead over Labour by about  per cent - enough for a comfortable majority.But in some surveys, the gap has fallen to just  points, while one poll at the weekend suggested a Conservative majority of just .Moreover, as the last two General Elections proved, the polls can be badly wrong. The result this time could go down to the wire.What the country needs to ensure Corbyn’s defeat is a vast coalition of voters united by the one aim of keeping him out of Downing Street.This was meant to be the Brexit election but it has rightly turned into a referendum on Corbyn’s spectacular unfitness for high office.And the only result should be a wholesale rejection of his bid for power.To achieve that, all anti-Corbyn voters – no matter what their past allegiances or their personal hostility to Johnson – must vote tactically for the Conservatives.Jeremy Corbyn and his shadow Chancellor John McDonnell must be stoppedThroughout the campaign, Remain supporters have talked feverishly of the potential for anti-Tory tactical voting to stop Brexit.But far more potent would be a wave of pro-Tory tactical voting to keep out Corbyn.At the heart of such a drive must lie the millions of decent, patriotic voters in Labour’s heartlands of the North and the Midlands, who have backed the party all their lives but are now profoundly disillusioned with Corbyn.If they held their noses and supported Johnson, then Labour would face annihilation.There are already signs that this could be happening.The so-called “Red Wall” of around  Labour marginals from Yorkshire to Wales, characterised by seats like Bolsover in Derbyshire and Crewe in Cheshire, appears to be crumbling.If a new army of Red Tory voters materialises on Thursday, the damage to Corbyn could be phenomenal.This week were reports that Labour are even in trouble in Leigh, where Joanne Platt has a majority of almost , and which is only th on the Tories’ target list.Similarly, the latest poll in the Lincolnshire port of Grimsby, which has been held by Labour for generations, shows a big lead for the Tories.This mood of revolt against political loyalties was captured in the words of one café worker in Labour-held Wrexham, North Wales, who said at the weekend: “I’ve always voted Labour and my family always voted Labour. On Thursday I shall be voting Tory.”People like her recognise that traditional Labour – the party of Clem Attlee, John Smith and Tony Blair – is now dead, replaced by a dogmatic, intolerant movement dedicated to the overthrow of capitalism.The election campaign has only reinforced Labour’s unfitness for office.Lavish pledges of free services and extravagant spending increases have been dished out like confetti, shattering the last remnants of the party’s economic credibility.Meanwhile, Labour has nothing coherent to say about Brexit beyond the threat of yet more dither and delay.It is no wonder that the five million Labour voters who backed Leave in the  referendum are in such despair.Boris himself put it well on a visit to Grimsby yesterday when he said that Labour’s Brexit stance represented “the great betrayal, orchestrated from Islington by politicians who sneer at your values and ignore your votes.”But it is not just Leave voters who should back the Tories. Remainers who loathe the idea of a Corbyn regime should do so as well.A hard-left Government is too big a price for stopping Brexit, for which the British people democratically voted three years ago.The arch pro-EU Tory rebel Dominic Grieve, now standing as an independent in his Beaconsfield constituency, said recently that he was “absolutely satisfied that Mr Corbyn would be a disaster in Downing Street.”Yet Grieve is making that dire possibility more likely by trying to siphon off votes from the Tory party.Indeed, all the opposition parties are acting as Corbyn’s allies, whatever their protestations.Nigel Farage’s Brexit party, in particular, could still badly split the anti-Corbyn vote in a string of Northern and Midlands seats, like Hartlepool.The latest poll in the constituency shows the Brexit Party on  per cent and the Tories on  per cent, a far higher combined total of Labour’s  per cent.In Doncaster North, held by Ed Miliband, Labour is on  per cent against a combined total of  per cent for the Brexit Party and the Conservatives.Further south, a vote for Jo Swinson’s Liberal Democrats is realistically a vote for Corbyn, just as in Scotland, support for the SNP will help to propel Corbyn into Downing Street.The choice is stark. Our country’s security, liberty and growth can only be secured by theof a Conservative Government.There is nothing to fear from the continuation in office of Boris Johnson, who stands in the long tradition of one-nation Conservatism epitomised by Benjamin Disraeli and Winston Churchill.But there is everything to fear from Corbyn’s ascent to power.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe internet sensation of dogs at polling stations has ed once again in this yearaposs general election. And this year some of the biggest names in politics are also taking part. Boris Johnson walked his rescue puppy to a polling station just yards from Downing Street. And London Mayor Sadiq Khan took his pet Labrador with him to cast his ballot. The dogs at polling stations phenomenon began when voters posted photos of their pooches waiting patiently outside while they voted. Each election thousands of photos appear online with the hashtag #dogsatpollingstations. Have you spotted something unusual at a polling station  Email webnews@mirror Mr Johnson arrived at Central Methodist Hall in Westminster at around .am to cast his vote, bringing dog Dilyn along with him. The Prime Minister left around three minutes later, after posing for a picture with his pet. Meanwhile Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn was greeted by a small number of supporters as he arrived to cast his vote in north London.  A protester dressed as Elmo, a character from childrenaposs TV programme Sesame Street, was restrained by security guards as she tried to approach Mr Corbyn as he entered the polling station. He later posed for photographs with well-wishers outside the polling station. Mr Corbyn arrived to cast his vote at Pakeman Primary School in Islington with his we Laura Alez at around .am. Meanwhile, members of the public in a number of London constituencies have had to queue around street corners to vote in some of the busiest conditions they have seen. Iaposve voted at the same station and time for eight years, but have never had to queue before, said Craig Fordham, , from Putney, who had to wait for  minutes. Chris Schofield queued for  minutes in the Bermondsey and Old Southwark constituency.

Today is the first pre-Christmas election for almost  years.Festive dress for Rob Curtis :Jeremy Corbyn worried about some pictures from his early political career The Labour leader is trying every trick in the book to encourage supporters to go out and vote for him. :Queues at some polling stations There have been fears that the cold weather and short day could mean that voter turnout is lower than previous elections. But has the importance of this poll got through to the general public  Turnout will be absolutely key in some of the marginal seats.:Election day questionsPolling day brings with it a special set of rules and regulations to ensure that voting takes place in a free and fair atmosphere.- When do polls open and close Polls opened at am and polling must close at pm.However, the Electoral Commission says any eligible electors who at pm are in a queue inside or outside the polling station must be allowed to vote.- What happens to election coverage Under electoral law, discussion of politics by broadcast media, including the BBC, is not allowed while voting is under way.Broadcasters must also not publish the results of any opinion polls while people are voting.- When is the exit poll It will be announced live on the BBC, ITV and Sky News as soon as the polls close, and will offer the first clues as to how the night will unfold.- Do I need ID to vote If you live in England, Wales or Scotland you do not need to take any identication to vote however you will need to show photo ID in Northern Ireland.You do not have to take your polling card with you, but the Electoral Commission advises that having it with you can help speed up the process.- Can I use a pen to vote There will be a pencil in the polling booth, but voters can use a penthey prefer.The Electoral Commission warns voters not to write anything  on the paper - other than a cross in one box - or your vote may not be counted.If you make a mistake - as long as you have not already put it in the ballot box - polling station staff can give you a replacement ballot paper.- Can I take a photo Taking photos inside the polling station is not allowed as it risks the secrecy of voting.The Electoral Commission says you are welcome to take photos outside the polling station.:KEY EVENTBoris Johnson takes dog to vote with himThe Prime Ministerarrived at Methodist Central Hall this morning with dog Dilyn to cast his vote. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVoters are going to the polls across the UK to pick  MPs - and that will the decide our next Prime Minister. The polls have Boris Johnsonaposs Conservatives tipped to win either an overall House of Commons majority or the most seats in a hung parliament.Of course, anything is possible, andJeremy Corbynaposs Labour Party does win an overall majority it would have a radically dferent impact on Britainaposs future.So how will these radically dferent forks in the road impact the state of the UK  Our head of politics Jason Beattie has outlined the dferent options facing the UK. Boris Johnson wins an overall majority Brexit: The Prime Minister plans to railroad his withdrawal agreement through Parliament before Christmas to make sure we leave the EU by January . Far from getting Brexit done this triggers the start of months,not years, of trade talks with the EU and other countries, including the US, India and Australia.Johnson has pledged to get a trade deal with the EU by December . If he fails we could face a no-deal Brexit on that date. What happens next will depend on the size of the Tory majority. If Johnson wins comfortably he should be able to play for time butit is a narrow margin then he will be in hock to the hard Brexiteers in his party. Public services: The Tories have promised more nurses, extra money for schools and hospitals and , more police officers.But their spending plans only envisage more money for the NHS, with education, councils and the Home Office spending still below pre- levels. And they depend on what happens with Brexit. If there is no trade deal the economy could slide and the Tories will not have money to invest in public services. This could lead to a stinging backlash from voters.  The UK: The Conservatives’ Brexit plans could lead to the break up of the United Kingdom.Leaked Treasury documents showed that Northern Ireland will be “symbolically” cut off from the rest of the UK because it will remain under EU for trade and there will be checks on imports between the mainland and Ulster. Nicola Sturgeon will seize on the Tory majority and Johnson’s hard Brexit to press the case for another Scottish referendum. The leaders:Jeremy Corbyn will face calls to quit immediatelyhe loses a second general election .Allies of the Labour leader will try to persuade him to stay on with a view to installing a successor who will keep the Corbynite flame alive. A bitter leadership race could pitch the left of the party against moderates who argue Labour will only win power with a new leader who takes the party back towards the centre ground. Johnson will be safe for the foreseeable future as long as his Brexit plans do not become unstuck. Jo Swinson’s position depends on how well the Lib Dems perform. There is a hung Parliament  Brexit: Everything will depend on the numbers. Corbyn could become Prime Ministerthe SNP , Lib Dems and Plaid Cymru agree to work with him.Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson says she will only back LabourCorbyn steps aside. If Corbyn can form a government then he has promised to negotiate a new withdrawal agreement with the EU and put it to a referendum. Buthe is unable to form a government there could another election or Johnson has burnt his bridges with the DUP butthe numbers are tight he could try to strike a deal with the Lib Dems and the SNP - but they would demand a second referendum as the minimal price. Public services: Labour will want to press ahead with its plans to raise taxes on business and the richest %.Rail, water and the Royal Mail could be brought back into public ownership. There would be a big investment in social care, the NHS and education. The SNP is likely to support much of this but the Lib Dems are opposed to many of Labour’s policies. Could scrapping Trident be the price Labour pays for the SNP support   The UK: If Corbyn can form a Government with SNP support then a second Scottish referendum is highly likely.Labour has indicated this would be an issue for later in the parliamentary term. A new Brexit deal is unlikely to isolate Northern Ireland as Corbyn is looking for an agreement that keeps the whole of the UK in a customs union. The leaders: What happens to the leaders will depend on the result and who can form a government. If the numbers fall in Labour’s favour and Corbyn becomes PM then Boris Johnson may try to cling on as leader.But he will be under pressure to quit having thrown away the Tory lead in the polls and the chance for a fourth term in government. Jo Swinson could find herself in the role of kingmaker evenher party failed to make headway at the election. Jeremy Corbyn wins a overall majority

story: NewsWhy Queen, Kate Middleton and other royals dont vote - even though theyre allowed toThe Queen, Kate Middleton, Princes Charles, William and Harry wont be heading to the polling station to vote in the  General ElectionShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  DEC NewsSorry guys! "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email As we all prepare to cast our votes in the  General Election , there are a group of people who wonapost be heading out to the polling station - the Royal Family.While many believe the Queen and her relatives arenapost allowed to put an X on the ballot paper this isnapost actually the case.The truth is, the Queen can vote. She is eligible and perfectly within her rights to go out and have her say.But you probably wonapost spot her down the local polling station, and the same goes for Prince Charles, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and other members of The Firm. The monarch is entitled in law to cast a ballot in general elections, but royal tradition sees her choose to abstain. By convention the Queen doesnapost vote, rather than because of a legal impediment, says an Electoral Commission spokesman. Historian and author Sarah Gristwood says itaposs consistently been a policy of this Queen, since her early days as head of state, to stay completely above the fray. It follows on from a major reinvention of the monarchy following the end of World War One and the establishment of the House of Windsor. Even though she doesnapost vote, the Queen does have a very important role to play after the results have been announced.  The leader of the winning party will travel to Buckingham Palace where they will have a meeting with the Monarch during which she will ask them to form a Government on her behalf. Boris Johnson plans to hold a stripped-back Queenaposs Speech just days before Christmashe wins.Similar to the one we saw after the snap  election, it will be a much quicker affair without the usual pomp and ceremony.

story: NewsUKs oldest volunteer, , has served more than ,, cups of teaPeggy Maskrey still spends three days a week helping out at the busy Charles Thompson Mission, close to her home in Birkenhead and has been doing so for the past  yearsShareCommentsByClaire Donnelly:,  DEC NewsThe UKs oldest volunteer Peggy Maskrey, aged , who is still donating her time "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShe’s been serving hot tea, home-made soup and a hefty helping of kindness to homeless people in her community since long before most of us were born. And at  years young, Britain’s oldest volunteer - the amazing Peggy Maskrey - is showing no sign of slowing down. The selfless pensioner still spends three days a week helping out at the busy Charles Thompson Mission, close to her home in Birkenhead - just like she’s been doing for the past  years. Peggy, who met her late husband Ted at the Mission, first came here as a shy schoolgirl in . As an adult she waitressed by day and volunteered at night before switching to day shts when she retired in .Now - after serving more than a million brews and hundreds of gallons of wholesome chicken soup - she says the fact she and her colleagues are still needed is a damning indictment of modern Britain. Taking a break from the serving hatch where visitors queue to say hello, she explains: “People are still in need aren’t they  It hasn’t gone away and that’s very sad. It shocks me really. “People still come here cold, hungry or lonely. It used to be men but now we see all kinds of people women, families, all sorts. “We used to have a lot of children coming here, a long time ago, when I was young, the children would be outside, barefoot, now we are seeing them coming to us again.” Her hazel eyes flashing, she leans in to clasp my hand and adds: “Children are suffering today. Today, children still need shoes. “When I started here there was no money from the social and we didn’t have anything like the NHS - you paid for the doctor - but we thought things would get better when they came in. “It’s supposed to be that the government give people the money they need - people shouldn’t be poor - but it’s not working out like that is it  “You don’t knowchildren are getting to see that money, you don’t know what’s going on but for a lot of these people things aren’t getting better.  “Now there are a lot of people sleeping in parks, in doorways - I never saw that when I was growing up. “There are more young people coming here who are homeless, that’s one thing I’ve noticed recently, people who need help here are getting younger. “We get young mums in who don’t have the things they need for their babies - nappies and bedding or clothes. “So you can’t really say things have got better. “All we can do is make sure that anyone who comes here feels welcome and gets a hot meal and anything  we have. “Everyone deserves that. It’s just a shame we’re still having to help people in this day and age.” Peggy is part of a dedicated volunteer team that does just that - serving up hot meals and drinks to  people a day, as well as providing second-hand clothes and household items, to anyone that needs them. When the Mission was founded,  years ago by a local philanthropist, it aimed to provide people with crisis support, solidarity and the odd treat. Run entirely on donations, there is still no means testing and no referrals system, just help given freely to anyone who asks for it.  Peggy smiles as she remembers being presented with rag dolls with hand-sewn clothes and painted faces at Christmas time, the joy of her mum’s puddings made with milk from the Mission and winter nights spent watching ‘Magic Lantern’ shows with her friends. These days young people are still a priority with baby equipment and a Christmas toy bank two of the newer services provided. And Peggy isn’t looking to hang up her tabard any time soon. After having a double knee replacement seven years ago she seems in fine health. She doesn’t even wear glasses and is positively nimble on her feet. Last night she was out after being invited to switch on Birkenhead’s Christmas lights and as she reels off details of the youth clubs she used to visit, her memory seems better than mine. And as manager, Bernie Frost, , says, Peggy isn’t some kind of volunteer mascot - she’s a vital part of this team. “She’s brilliant,” he says. “Everyone knows here and she really is the heart of the place.” As people start queuing to come in, cold and wet, ready to warm up and get something to eat, Peggy jumps up to help. “I’ve done every job here,” she says, smiling and gesturing to me to follow her. “I’ve scrubbed this floor many times, when it was all floorboards. “If I see a job needs doing, I just get on with it. “That’s what I’m here for. If I was at home I’d get lonely. “If you don’t get out you’re not meeting people, I’m here with friends. I’d encourage anyone - no matter how old they are - to volunteer.”  So what’s the secret to her health and vitality  Patting her lilac-tinged hair, she says: “Maybe it was all those pans of scouse or the broth, the sheep’s head soup, we used to have at home that’s kept me going. “My sister lived until she was  and my brothers all lived into their eighties. “I make myself a hot meal every day do all my own cleaning. I don’t really sit about. Why would you ” Last year her letime’s work was rewarded with an MBE. She travelled to London to receive the accolade with two of her nieces and her cherished grandson.  “It was wonderful,” she says, her eyes filling with tears. Prince Charles held my hand the whole time. “It was such an honour and a very special day. I’ll never forget it, being there with the family.” Typically modest, she adds: “But I’ve only done what other people done, just for a bit longer. “There is a good sense of community here, there always has been, that’s never gone away. “When I was younger we’d sell pansies for the Mission, I’d take mine round the pubs on a Friday night and my tin would be full with money. It’s the same now, people are kind.” It seems like a daft question but I have to ask it. Will she ever retire

title: what its really like general
story: NewsopinionWhat its really like to be a general election candidate on voting day - by ex-MP Tristram HuntElection Day is both a political decision on the big issues of the day, but also a very personal judgement on your character - by your neighbours, local newsagents and publicans, even extended family members.ShareCommentsByTristram Hunt:,  DEC NewsopinionTristram Hunt was Labour Party education spokesman before quitting to run the VA museum "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Labour Cabinet Minister Tony Benn always loved polling day: the stubby pencil the ramshackle church hall the metallic ballot box and the familiar dance of democracy in action. ‘Having been to hundreds of polling stations in my le,’ he wrote, ‘I have come to regard them as almost sacred in character.’ Not all candidates feel the same. Even in the safest of Parliamentary seats, you awake with dread on election morn. Facing you that day is the most public and potentially humiliating Performance Review that any HR department could have dreamt up. Election Day is both a political decision on the big issues of the day, but also a very personal judgement on your character - by your neighbours, local newsagents and publicans, even extended family members. It is also a day that never seems to end. You start early with a am leaflet drop to catch those going to the polls before work. It’s a last minute appeal, but the electorate is a fickle bunch who often only decide where their cross will fall once inside the polling booth. Then it’s back to base - known as Committee Rooms in the Labour Party - for a hot breakfast before the grind of ‘knocking up.’With lists of identied voters , the key task is to GOTV - Get Out The Vote. And, oh, it can be dispiriting stuff trying to convince the electorate to fulfil their civic duty that previous generations have sacriced so much for. ‘It looks like it might rain.’ ‘I’m just waiting for my we to come back.’ ‘I’ve lost my polling card.’ ‘Sorry. Not interested’ are just some of the most familiar excuses. By .am, the excitement of democracy can begin to pail. But then it’s time for the high street stall the drive around with the loudspeaker on the car and visiting other committee rooms to thank supporters and strong-arm volunteers. Lunch has to be taken as showily as possible, generously supporting the local café or pub – sometimes both. An army marches on its stomach, and canvassers need a good spread. Before you know it, it is balloon and leaflet time at the primary school gate. There are now tiresomely strict rules about politicking near playgrounds, but a few stickers and flags for the Year s never goes amiss. Then the long slog until polls close at pm. Right up until the wire, house by house street by street chasing down every potential voter. Sometimes knocking on the same door a good three times to make sure of that much promised support.

story: NewsCouple told leave home now as coastal erosion leaves it m from clfEXCLUSIVE: Juliet Blaxlands home she shares with husband Giles Stibbe in Easton Bavents, near Southwold in Suffolk, will soon fall into the sea after a shocking increase in coastal erosionShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  DEC NewsJuliet said the home is a local landmark "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple have been told to quit their home before it falls into the North Sea after storms caused a .-metre section of clf to crumble. Juliet Blaxland, , told the Mirror in September that she believed her home, one the furthest east in the UK, would be safe for at least five years. But violent autumn storms, alongside big tides, triggered a dramatic increase in erosion, with nine metres of land lost in the past four months. After the .-metre section fell away overnight in a “cataclysmic event” last week, engineers found the row of three cottages was now  metres from the clf and unsafe. Juliet and husband Giles Stibbe, , will move home next week. Juliet said: “We knew all along it would eventually be demolished but it has caught us by surprise, as we could have reasonably expected another year here. “But ever since we moved in we were always aware of how little time we had left.  “Demolition is incredibly sad. It’s the end of an era.” She said that the house is a “landmark” in Easton Bavents, East Suffolk. The village, north of Southwold, used to have a church, a thriving market and many houses. But unrelenting erosion has virtually des­­troyed the community. Juliet and Army veteran Giles moved into the ham­­let  years ago, renting from the local farmer. Since then they have seen the demolition of several houses and the disappearance of the land between them and the sea. And engineers have now told the farm owner that all cottage tenants should leave. Demolition crews are expected to raze the homes over Christmas.  Architect Juliet and Giles are moving up the coast to the village of Benacre. The area suffers from erosion, too, but their new home is far enough inland to be safe... for now. Coastal Partnership East, a group formed by several local councils, has been monitoring the situation.

Colin Ainsworth, , from Liverpool, had entered the McDonaldaposs in Widnes during heavy rain when he stepped onto  floor tiles and fell down. A hearing at Cheshire Coroneraposs Court, heard how witnesses rushed to help, including an off-duty fire officer and a nurse assistant who tried to give CPR. Meanwhile, a member of staff went to NHS Widnes Urgent Care Centre to find a defibrillator but was told it wasnapost permitted for community use, the Liverpool Echo reports. Emma Newhouse, who was eating in the restaurant with friends, told the hearing by the time they found one, paramedics had arrived and were giving CPR. Miss Newhouse said: Colin got by our table and slipped onto his knees. He kind of smiled to laugh it off but he slowly landed on his back.  I went over, checkedhe was OK, checked his pulse because he wasn’t speaking and then the McDonald’s staff said that maybe he should be put in the recovery . We put him into the recovery then I said we needed to start CPR straight away. After the off-duty firefighter took over CPR, Miss Newhouse switched to checking Mr Ainsworth’s pulse – and asked for a defibrillator. She said: I did shout for a defib but the McDonald’s didn’t have one so one of the McDonald’s staff went to the NHSup the road but the NHS actually declined the defib, so we continued doing the CPR until the paramedics came.  In a statement read by assistance coroner for Cheshire, off-duty firefighter Russell Hardman said he had sat down with his food when he heard a someone telling someone to put a man in the recovery position. The qualied first responder stepped in and gave CPR for roughly around - minutes, although he said it could have been longer, until the paramedics arrived and took over. In a written statement, McDonald’s duty manager Roy Bartsch said he rang  and relayed information as needed and confirmed that an ambulance had been allocated. title: scotlands chernobyl housing estate cheapest
story: NewsScotlands Chernobyl housing estate with cheapest property in UK to be demolishedSome of the flats on the Clune Park estate, in Port Glasgow, Inverclyde, are in such poor condition that they pose a health risk - only around  people still live thereShareCommentsByRosemary LowneSarah WardChiara Fiorillo:,  DEC NewsClune Park, Port Glasgow, Inverclyde, has been described as ghost town "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA housing estate dubbed Scotlandaposs Chernobyl is set to be demolished next year. The Clune Park estate, in Port Glasgow, Inverclyde, is now home to about  people living in only some of the  flats.Property on the estate was once the cheapest in the UK, with one flat selling for just £, at auction, the Daily Record reports.The area however has been plagued with arsonists, causing shops, a primary school and a church to be abandoned. Plans to demolish the blocks created tensions between the council and private landlords who were refusing to sell up. The leader of Inverclyde Council, Stephen McCabe, previously said: It is a decimated, isolated community. It is a blight on the landscape. It is one of first things you see coming into Port Glasgow on the train. It would remind you of somewhere like Chernobyl. It is hoped next year bulldozers could move in to demolish the estate. We are progressing our strategy of acquiring all the properties to demolish them and we are progressing closing orders, Mr McCabe said.It has been a long haul to get here. We are continuing to engage with people who have properties in the area and we are trying to reach agreements with them in terms of acquiring the properties. Officers are hopeful that some time next year, we may well have sufficient properties that we can start to demolish in terms of at least one of the blocks.  Things are moving forward. I can see the end game. Some of the flats on the estate, which in the early part of the th century was home to shipyard workers, are in such poor condition that they pose a health risk.  Councillor Michael McCormick, Convener of Inverclyde Councilaposs Environment and Regeneration Committee, said: In the councilaposs opinion all of the flats on the estate are Below the Tolerable Standard- they donapost meet the basic requirements to be classed as fit for people to live in. And the results of several, recent, independent surveys have done nothing to change this view. The poor physical and social conditions in the area, combined with the level of input required from Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue and Inverclyde Council, clearly shows that the private housing market has failed and that large-scale, planned intervention is urgently needed.  Six buildings now have active Demolition Orders against them. The council is working towards demolishing all the buildings and clearing the site to allow this neglected part of Port Glasgow to be regenerated. A decade ago it was estimated that it would cost £.million to refurbish these buildings.  They have deteriorated even more since then. We are making steady progress in terms of acquiring these undesirable properties. But the remaining owners need to recognise that the only future for these homes is demolition and, frankly, the sooner the better. Mr McCabe added: We will continue to work and engage with the Scottish Government and call for them to support us with our strategy in terms of acquiring properties and potentially provide some funding for new a new build development on the site.

title: woman 23 hasnt been toilet
story: NewsWoman, , hasnt been to toilet for five years after her bladder nearly explodedPollyanna Love had suffered from painful bladder infections since she was just four and was left in agony until doctors removed the organ completelyShareByJane LavenderAssistant EditorErin Cardf:,  DEC NewsPollyanna suffers from an incredibly rare condition "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPollyanna Love hasnapost been able to go to the toilet for the last five years after her bladder nearly exploded. Surgeons had no choice but to remove her bladder and fit a stoma bag after the -year-old was diagnosed with a rare condition, Fowlers Syndrome. Pollyanna was just  when she had to undego the harrowing procedure because of her condition, which means the where the urethral sphincter – the muscle that keeps people continent – cannot relax, preventing normal urination.  Since the age of four Pollyanna had suffered from almost constant bladder infections and had to endure a burning sensation every time she went for a wee. But five years ago the pain was so bad she couldnapost pass water at all and AE doctors had to drain three litres of urine from her bladder and she was diagnosed with Fowlers Syndrome.  In July last year, because Pollyanna was suffering from bladder spasms so painful she said it was like being in labour, doctors removed her organ. She has been fitted with a stoma and has an attachable pouch to collect her waste. Pollyanna, of Ilkeston, Derbyshire, who is unable to work because of her condition, said: I’d been dealing with bladder infections for as long as I could remember, even as young as about four or five years old.  For years, I’d have that feeling of desperately needing the loo – but only be able to squeeze out a little dribble when I went.  Then, aged , I suddenly stopped being able to wee all together. It was absolute agony and horric to face something like that so young. I’ve had to grow up very quickly. Pollyanna was given antibiotics everytime she suffered a bladder infection but as soon as she stopped taking them the problem ed.  She said: I’d have to wear incontinence pads to school. I felt disgusting and didn’t tell anybody what was going on. It really affected my confidence.  I constantly felt desperate for the loo, but I had absolutely no idea what was causing it.  I thought I was just unlucky, and one of those people that are prone to infections like cystitis, which I know some girls are. Pollyanna tried everything to cure her symptoms, including cutting out certain foods, but nothing worked.  Then, aged , she “went into retention” for the first time, meaning she could not empty her bladder at all.  She said: I’d had quite a severe asthma attack, and literally couldn’t wee afterwards. Doctors thought that it may be the trauma that had caused it, and eventually, I was able to urinate again.   “But over the next two years, I found myself being able to wee less and less. But then in March , while she was working in Boots head office, Pollyanna realised she couldnapost remember the last time she had passed water. She was also so bloated she looked nine months pregnant. Pollyanna said: Once I realised that I wasn’t sure when I’d last had a wee, I panicked and downed a load of water, hoping to flush everything out.  Looking back, it was the worst thing I could have done, as it was adding even more strain to my bladder – but at the time, I didn’t know what was wrong with me.  Soon afterwards, I began feeling really unwell. Eventually, I was sick, and my colleagues phoned an ambulance. At AE a scan revealed how dangerously full her bladder was and medics inserted a catheter – to drain away three litres of urine. This is six times as much as a fully ing bladder can hold. Pollyanna said: My bladder was close to exploding. Nobody could understand why I hadn’t been able to wee.  Taught to self-catheterise by hospital staff Pollyanna found struggled with dealing with the issue. She said: My bladder would spasm and so sometimes clamp shut around the catheter itself, which was absolute agony. Pollyanna had a raft of tests and was finally diagnosed with Fowlers Syndrome, which typically affects women in their s and s, in June . She said: In a way, it was almost a relief to be diagnosed, as I’d genuinely started to wonderit was all in my head and whether my problem was psychological.  Pollyanna had a suprapubic catheter inserted into the bladder through a cut in the tummy. It enabled her to drain away urine before it built up to a dangerous level but her spasms were still almost unbearable. She was rushed to hospital again in September, , after her family found her screaming on the floor. Pollyanna said: The only way I can describe it is that it felt like I was giving birth to my bladder.  I was screaming and screaming. In that moment, I was ready to die, the pain was that bad.  The nurses at hospital were lovely but Fowlers is still so little-known, even in the medical community, that nobody was sure what to do with me.  In the end, the only thing that helped calm the spasms was gas and air as that would relax my body. But even then, they’d soononce the effects wore off.” For the next few months, Pollyanna’s le was blighted by Fowlers Syndrome with her regularly having toto hospital for gas and air when her spasms became too painful. Then, in December, medics mentioned they could perform an urostomy operation, to create a new exit route for urine via an opening in the abdomen, known as a stoma.  Desperate to end her suffering Pollyanna went ahead with the six-hour operation in February .

CCTV footage shows the suspect, surnamed Li, wandering around the corridors of the maternity ward before walking out of a room with the baby girl in her arms on December  -  hours before her arrest. Authorities in the county of Huishui in south-western China’s Guizhou Province were alerted to the suspected kidnapping by the baby’s mother, Chen Ming-xin, and her husband Mr Lu. The couple were reportedly among  people, including three other new mums, who were resting in the room at Lianjiang Hospital at the time of the incident. Ms Chen and Mr Lu said they would offer a cash reward of up to , yuanfor any information about their missing daughter, before Huishui police announced that they had arrested Li in her rental home just  feet away two days later. The couple were then reunited with their daughter, who was found healthy and unharmed. Recalling the scare, Mr Lu said he and his we had been fast asleep in the early hours of the morning, with their daughter resting on his spouse’s bed.  They woke to find their daughter missing, and hospital nurses were clueless as to her possible whereabouts. An inspection of the CCTV footage showed Li wearing a nurse unorm and surgical mask, but staff at the hospital said she was not one of their nursing staff. Ms Chen told local media: “I woke up and my daughter was gone. “The mother in the bed next to mine said she was carried away by a woman in a nurse unorm. “I wondered why she didn’t tell me, but she thought the woman was a real nurse.  “The suspect actually wanted to take her baby, but she wasn’t successful because she woke up. “That’s when she decided to take mine instead.” Ms Chen claims the hospital changing room, which is full of nurse unorms, is not locked and can be accessed by any members of the public.

title: dark blues squad a bit short says mcpake ahead of transfer window
story: Manager James McPake is finalising plans for some winter additions to improve his struggling Dundee side as the January transfer window nears.In the summer, the Dens gaffer brought in a dozen new faces as the club aimed to recover quickly from Premiership relegation.He accepts that’s taken longer than everyone at the club had hoped but has vowed that will be the last window with wholesale changes to the Dark Blues playing squad.James said: “We’re speaking about how we’re going to recruit and what is needed in this window and the next to make us better.“We have been looking ahead at the January window since the summer. Everybody in this league would want to add quality to their squad.“Looking at the bench on Saturday at Arbroath, we are a bit short. If we get a couple of injuries then you are short but you are always looking to improve anyway.“I’ve said before, I don’t want to go back to chopping and changing  players or whatever every window. That has happened for a number of windows at this club and that has to stop.“That’s why we were so busy in the summer so we don’t have to keep doing that. It has taken a bit of time to get everything right since then.“We are looking where we are short and what we can add but it has to be quality not just to add numbers to bulk up the squad for the second half of the season.”Next up for the Dark Blues is a home clash with one of the form sides in the ision at the moment, Dunfermline.Since Dundee have taken just one point from their last , Stevie Crawford’s Pars have racked up three wins on the spin.“It shows you what can happen,” added James. “We’ve kind of switched. title: vomiting syndrome ruined my life dundee woman relives horror of condition which saw her vomiting more than six times an hour
story: A woman has relived the horror of a rare condition which at its worst left her vomiting more than six times an hour.Nicola Montague was hospitalised more than  times between the ages of five and  as a result of Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome.Her horric health problems eventually led to her developing agoraphobia, and she lost five years of her le through being housebound.The -year-old, from Fintry Mains, said: “I would feel perfectly well and healthy, then out of the blue I would start vomiting to the point of six times or more an hour.“I couldn’t keep down even a tiny sip of water and would eventually start bringing up bile, stomach acid and blood.“This would led to dehydration and I would have to go to hospital for IV fluids and paracetamol through an IV line and a strong anti-emetic to stop the vomiting.”“I would put on a brave face and joke about how, with the internet, there was no better time to be an agoraphobe, but really I was extremely isolated and lonely.”She said: “During one attack when I was , I had to stop and vomit in public every  to  steps, all the way home, even being sick on the bus.“I remember the terror of trying to get home, back to safety.”It got so intense that Nicola had suicidal thoughts at the age of  and was given medication for depression and anxiety, which eased the severity of the attacks. vw, px"  But the lasting impact was nerve damage in her stomach, gastroparesis, and a fear of leaving her home and being sick outside.Although she was aware of what she was missing, Nicola says she was absolutely terried of leaving the house.Her agoraphobia was triggered by traumatic experiences she endured due to her vomiting condition.Nicola became heavily dependent on her parents and sister, who she lives with, and online friendships. She spent most of her time alone in her bedroom.One day she randomly bought an embroidery kit online and became hooked on having a task and “creating something beautul”, improving her feeling of self-worth in the process.Inspired, she was suddenly eager to take part in crafting sessions to learn more but could only manage a few steps outside the door.Nicola said: “Everyone was out living their lives and to me an achievement would be only napping once a day, instead of three times.“When I first started going out again it was terrying. I felt so shaky and unsure of everything.“I’d been in the house so long that one of our downstairs neighbours who moved in four years earlier didn’t even know I lived there.“I knew from research it was important not to push myself into things too fast, so I stopped at the end of the path.“Turning around to go back inside was a huge relief and getting back into our flat was like being wrapped in a big safety blanket but I soon became aware of how confined I was inside.” vw, px"  Nicola slowly began to attend crafting workshops with her parents also in attendance, the first of which was a puppet making class ran by How It Felt.The social enterprise uses puppet-making and drama sessions to encourage people to talk about mental health issues, which Nicola says played a huge part in her recovery journey.From there she got the confidence to join other crafting groups and started an online distance learning course with the Embroiderer’s Guild to ease back into studying.Nicola says she still often feels unwell but the intensity has reduced to such an extent that she hopes to one day study at Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design.

title: heres how this aberdeen foodbank prepares the vital parcels to help those most in need
story: From being handed in to being given out to those in need, the journey of food donations is a ied one.Aberdeen-based initiative and foodbank CFINE has revealed some secrets of the trade and detailed what exactly happens to donated products such as tinned soup and pasta.The social enterprise is urging more people to get involved with the Original  Christmas appeal to aid its coffers.The appeal, backed by the Evening Express, is well under way.Graeme Robbie, Fareshare manager at CFINE, explained the process donations go from arrival to distribution.He said: “Firstly, all of the food comes in and everything is documented and checked for damage.“We have a team of volunteers who will go through everything just to date check it and sort it into dferent types of food.“This is then packaged up into food parcels that are distributed from our own foodbank and also other foodbanks and food providers right across Aberdeen.“We’ve got an extensive network of partners and work with a whole range of community organisations to ensure the food is going to folk who need it.”A food parcel normally consists of three days’ worth of products and includes beans, soup, pasta and tinned veg, plus a little sweet treat like tinned fruit.CFINE has noticed a substantial rise in foodbank use over the last year and now wants to make sure they are well stocked up heading into the busy festive period.They are part of a wider network called the Food Poverty Action Aberdeenformed of a number of organisations including Aberdeen City Council and Aberdeen Cyrenians. vw, px"  Mr Robbie highlighted the importance of the initiative to the whole of Grampian.He said: “Our aim is to tackle poverty and improve health and wellbeing in Aberdeen and the surrounding area and run the busiest foodbank here.“This year we will distribute over , food parcels and also run Fareshare Grampian, which redistributes surplus food that would otherwise go to waste.“CFINE is pivotal to tackling these issues and supporting vulnerable iniduals and families across the north-east.”Products such as non-perishable items like tinned soup and beans, plus pasta, cereals and biscuits, are in high demand locally.CFINE does not rely solely on donations for its parcels and is involved in a number of dferent schemes.As part of Fareshare Mr Robbie talks to the food industry to redistribute food that would otherwise go to waste, like short-dated products that people are not buying. However, for non-perishable items, the public is needed to donate, with more than  food parcels given out a day.How you can help Original #s Christmas Appeal" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local how-you-can-help-original-s-christmas-appeal embed # secretOtGyJdwAL" data-secret"OtGyJdwAL" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Mr Robbie added: “We cover Aberdeen predominantly but for example, Fareshare Grampian operates now into the Highlands and Islands.“However, given the scale and need on our own doorstep, that is where this food will be used.”

title: dons of the decade vote pick your left back for our aberdeen team of the last 10 years
story: With the end of the decade drawing near, we’re asking you to pick your Aberdeen team from the last  years.Over the coming days, we’ll work from the man between the sticks to the player leading the line, asking you to choose from several options for each position.Given it’s the formation the Dons have used most over the period in question, we’ve already decided the team will line-up as a ---.Here are your options for left-back. Once you’ve decided, select the player#s name at the bottom of the page.Derby County left-back Lowe made  appearances for the Reds last term, including  starts # despite it looking like he#d be spending the second half of the campaign back at his parent club.Lowe was excellent in the three wins over Rangers # two at Ibrox and one at Hampden # and the fans were desperate to see the talented wing-backfor this season.A bonafide Aberdeen legend, recently making his th appearance, Considine has spent his entire career going between centre-back and left-back for the Dons.However, he#s played most of his games in the latter position.In terms of achievements in this decade, among other things, there was a crucial goal against Motherwell and helping to keep it tight at the back during the   League Cup run.A Considine goal also ended a -year winless league run at Celtic Park on the last day of the   campaign.Leigh joined Aberdeen on loan at the start of this season from Dutch outfit NAC Breda, when it became clear Lowe wouldn#t be ing, although the terms of the agreement mean he will likely remain at the Dons permanently.He immediately impressed the Red Army, scoring against Chikhura Sachkhere in Europa League qualying.Because of injuries in midfield this season, Leigh has shown versatility to play further forward, in the middle of the park and on the wing. However, there is no doubt his best position is as a marauding left wing-back.A product of the Aberdeen youth academy, Robertson has spent the last few years in England with Blackpool and Rotherham United.However, as a youngster in the early part of the decade he made  Dons starts, before knee problems hampered his progress.Clark Robertson, left.Keep an eye out for votes on the other positions and the final Dons of the Decade team over the next couple of weeks.
