title: £36m tourism case nearing completion
story: AN outline business case designed to pave the way for a poundm investment in a flagship tourism project in Newcastle is expected to be completed next May.A series of ambitious plans mdash including a gondola ride into the heart of the Mournes mdash have been outlined to revolutionise tourist facilities in the resort and signicantly increase visitor numbers.Included among the proposals is an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy.The highly ambitious proposals are among key projects included in Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos bid for a share of poundbn investment package under the Belfast City Regional Deal.The local authority has appointed a dedicated team to deliver the outline business case designed to pave the way to secure funding to help build the project. An economist is also helping compile the document.City deals are packages of funding and decision making powers which allow councils to boost the economy through the development of large projects in their respective areas.The deals are designed to allow councils to take charge and responsibility of decisions that affect their area, do what they think is best to help businesses grow, create economic growth and decide how public money should be spent.Newry, Mourne and Down is one of five local authorities paired with Belfast City Council, universities and theprivate sector who have committed poundm to help deliver a raft of schemes across the Province, with the remainder of the cash expected to come from the Treasury and Northern Ireland Executive.At this weekrsquos meeting of the councilrsquos Enterprise, Tourism and Regeneration Committee, politicians were told that officials have been working on the detailed outline business case since last May, with a consultancy team helping prepare the document.Council officials say that when work on the business case is completed next spring, it will provide a detailed analysis and assessment of the projectrsquos strategic fit within the City Deal.In addition, the document will also outline detailed project costs, the benefits, risks and funding requirements.Politicians were told this week that the documentrsquos analysis will recommend a particular procurement route in order to deliver the scheme.It has also been confirmed that the ongoing development of the business case involves planning considerations and the development of exemplar design and output specications, prior to any formal procurement exercise being undertaken.Politicians were informed on Monday night that the outline business case will provide detail on the technical expertise in terms of the design, construction and maintenance of similar international attractions and also provide detailed analysis of commercial operations of a visitor attraction of this scale.It is understood that council officials are working alongside Tourism NI to secure financial backing for other aspects of the tourism investment and support to move the projects through a series of key stages, including the preparation of business cases and planning approval.Other aspects of the Mournes Gateway scheme include an elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park, a new visitor centre and bird hide at the Murlough Nature Reserve and a new bridge constructed under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge on the outskirts of the town.Consultants appointed by the local authority to look at developing the resortrsquos visitor infrastructure have also come up with proposals for the Islands Park, with upgrades planned for existing car parks, alongside new public toilet provision.There are also proposals to reduce the the tree line in Donard Forest on the slopes of the Mournes, with a so-called green travel network which would allow visitors to hire bicycles and electric bikes to make their way round ious attractions is also suggested.The ious proposals form the core of the so-called Mourne Mountains Gateway Study and have already been discussed with the National Trust, Forest Service and Environment Agency and other key players..prettyPhoto

title: Air Ambulance thanks accountancy firm
story: A LEADING chartered accountancy firm with offices in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards has been thanked by Air Ambulance NI after it donated thousands of pounds to the charity.M B McGrady and Co is no stranger to offering support throughout the local community and its sponsorship initiatives and charitable donations have seen numerous local and regional organisations go from strength to strength.A charity partner with Air Ambulance NIfor the past two years, the accountancy practice has raised over pound, through a number of successful events, including the lsquoUltimate Aqua Challengersquo in .Earlier this year, M B McGrady and Co held the first ever lsquoBeer and Bubblesrsquo charity km at Finnebrogue Wood outside Downpatrick.MB McGrady  Co director Conaill McGrady said the firm was delighted to be able to support Air Ambulance NI.He continued: ldquoThe work that the charity does is truly remarkable, soour donation can even just go a small way to helping them then it is all worthwhile.ldquoA very big thank you goes to all those people who sponsored, donated, gave their time and helped in some way, without whom the fundraising would not be possible.Kerry Anderson, AANIrsquos head of fundraising, said she was delighted with the response to the localcompanyrsquos events to raise money on its behalf.ldquoMB McGrady have held some fantastic events, unique and fun for all the family and that brought the community together to raise money for and raise awareness of the work of the Air Ambulance.ldquoThe Helicopter Emergency Medical Serviceis tasked on average every single day. To ensure this is sustained, we need to raise poundm each year so public support is crucial.She added: ldquoThe money raised by M. B. McGrady during the course of the partnership will make a lesaving dference and help towards maintaining the high level of services provided by Air Ambulance NI..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch could lose Post Office with postmaster retiring
story: BALLYNAHINCH could be left without a Post Office in the New Year.The current Post Office in Lisburn Street is due to close on January  after the postmaster announced his resignation.Post Office officials hope that the closure will be temporary, but there are fears thatno one comes forward to take over the service, the market town will be left without a dedicated post office for the first time in generations.Post Office officials have confirmed that they are currently investigating a number of options with a view to retaining the service for the local community.They say that as part of examining the ious options, it is critical that any future service is sustainable, both for the person operating the service and for Post Office Limited.Postal officials have also warned that future provision will reflect customer numbers and usage and may lead to the establishment of what is being described as an ldquoalternative type of service which could potentially be a new style local branch run alongside an established retail shop in newly refurbished premises, ldquocreating a more modern and convenient experience for customers.In a letter to local politicians, postal officials have apologised for the inconvenience the temporary closure in Ballynahinch may cause and hope that, in the meantime, customers will continue to use the townrsquos post office and neighbouring branches.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker says he hopes that someone in the business community will come forward to ensure post office services continue in Ballynahinch in the New Year.ldquoI believe this is an opportunity a local business should grasp to ensure that Ballynahinch retains its post office which provides a wide range of services, he continued.ldquoSeveral years ago, the future of the townrsquos post office was under threat when the former SuperValu store closed. Someone came forward and this was welcomed by elderly people who would not be forced to travel outside the town to access services.Cllr Walker says it is vital that Ballynahinch retains its dedicated postal office and appealed to someone the townrsquos business community to consider taking over the service.ldquoBallynahinch is Down Districtrsquos third largest town and it would be a body blowthe planned temporary closure became permanent, he said.ldquoThe bottom lines appears to be thatno one comes forward to offer to run the service it will close and that will impact on people across the community.ldquoThe role of local post offices has changed considerably over recent years, with many transferring to large supermarkets which ensured that they were open for much longer, including weekends.ldquoMany elderly people prefer to conduct their business at post offices, not banks. That is one of the many reasons why this vitally important service is not lost to Ballynahinch. A number of local post offices, which provide a much broader range of services including banking facilities, are now housed in retail premises.Cllr Walker added: ldquoIt is my hope that one of the major retailers in Ballynahinch will come forward to ensure that the service is not lost to the town. While the post offices are important to our major towns, many are also at the heart of rural communities across the district. For many, having access to their local post office is a leline..prettyPhoto

title: Bid for prestigious geopark status formally submitted
story: A BID to secure a world renowned tourism designation for an area stretching across a huge area from the Mournes to Strangford Lough has been formally submitted.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is seeking prestigious UNESCO geopark status for an area taking in the Mournes, Ring of Gullion and the Strangford and Lecale Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty which has the potential to generate millions of pounds in tourism revenue.This week, the local authority confirmed that the formal geopark bid has been submitted with officials hoping that it will be successful.Northern Irelandrsquos only other current geopark mdash the Marble Arch Caves in Fermanagh mdash contributes just over poundm to the economy.Those behind the ambitious plan to secure geopark status for a huge swathe of land covering theMournes, Ring of Gullion and Strangford Lough, are confident thatsecured, the international designation can help transform the local economy.It has been revealed thatsuccessful, the geopark brand will use the geological heritage of the three areas to develop sustainable tourism that generates economic benefits, while providing recreational opportunities and increased awareness of the arearsquos natural assets, working with landowners, businesses and communities.An examination of geoparks reveals that typical activities include the development of walking and cycling trails, training local people to act as guides, the provision of information signs and the development of visitor centres.The ultimate aim of a geopark is to enhance the economy and develop employment opportunities for the people who live there, but the global brand does not impose any restrictions on farming practices, planning or development.Council officials say that securing geopark status is primarily about environmental sustainability and, at the same time, trying to increase economic revenue in a part of the world already revered for its stunning beauty.Geoparks are based around signicant areas of geology and are set up to support sustainable economic development of an area, primarily through geological and eco-tourism.But they are not just about geology and include sites that are of interest for their history, archaeology, bioersity, folklore, cultural and local heritage.Securing the prestigious geopark designation is one of the key planks of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos tourism strategy, with work on the designation application starting well over  months ago.Those behind the geopark designation are confident that it has the potential to deliver high quality tourism in the area, increasing the number of international visitors in particular. And while there is a signicant financial benefit for securing geopark status, council officials insist the benefits are not just economic.They have previously argued that geoparks have a ldquosignicant role to play in empowering local communities and giving them the opportunities to develop cohesive partnerships with the common goal of promoting the arearsquos signicant geological and other heritage.There are currently  geoparks found in  countries across the world, all of which have been developed using a bottom-up approach with local communities playing a signicant role in this process.Currently, there are three designated geoparks in Ireland. In addition to the Marble Arch Caves in Fermanagh, they include The Burren and Clfs of Moher in Co Clare and the Copper Coast geopark in Co Waterford.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokeswoman confirmed on Monday afternoon that the local authorityrsquos bid for geopark was formally submitted last month..prettyPhoto

title: Book delves into the history around Strangford
story: INVERBRENA Local History Group has launched the latest edition of its annual magazine mdash just in time for Christmas.Memories From Inverbrena: Strangford  features a selection of memories, stories, histories and photographs of people and places within the Strangford area, preserved for future generations.The magazine includes an article by Michael McConville in which he chronicles the history of the the local parish drama club during the s and s, including a selection of photographs of local amateur actors and actresses who participated in some of the popular well received productions.In his second article in this yearrsquos publication, Michael remembers happy days potato picking, recalling how everyone worked together as a team, both boys and girls, and all getting the same pay at the end of the day.Melanie Hamill puts pen to paper to provide an invaluable record of her splendid conversion of Strangford Presbyterian Church, earning it the prestigious  Heritage Angel award for Best Rescue of a Historic Building Or Place for projects under pound million. The building has also recently been awarded  stars by the Northern Irish Tourist Board.Eamon McMullan, with his wonderful gt for storytelling, charms readers with his tale of lsquoThe Little Folk of Kilclief By The Silent Searsquo, revealing to us all how the Chimney Rocks ldquoreally came in to existence.He also delights with his poem, lsquoThe Fairy Festivalrsquo, when the Little People came to sing, dance and play about Killard banks. Eamon also reminiscences about his joyful memories of lsquoA Village Childhoodrsquo in Strangford mdash his first friends, their pastimes, of when he became ldquoaffluent, less positive aspects and adventures, earning a ldquobob and of time spent as a ldquoreluctant Christian.Michael Howland from Ardglass takes a look at the history of the lighthouse on Rock Angus, investigating why the Ballast Board erected a lighthouse there but for some inexplicable reason did not place any light on it, resulting in shipwrecks occurring in its vicinity. It was not until  that a light was fitted, giving a red flash every five seconds, being converted to solar power in .Maurice Denvir relates how the idea of a community garden in Kilclief was first mooted and how the formation of the Kilclief Residents Association was instrumental in bringing the original idea to fruition.He details the ious stages, from the clearance of the site to its eventual transformation into the garden that exists today, something that would not have been possible without input from the many volunteers within the surrounding community who so generously offered their servicesIn lsquoMemories of The SS Georgetown Victoryrsquo, Eddie Wrightfrom Swindon vividly recalls the day in April  when he was aboard the ship when it ran aground on Killard Rocks.He remembers that following their rescue from the ship local farmers transported them to RAF coaches which drove them to the local airfield for breakfast. Later an Army convoy took them to Belfast Army barracks and at midnight on April  several hundred boarded an ordinary passenger steamer to Glasgow mdash which was their original destination.Joan Magee and Robert Connolly write about the history of Killard Point radar station, which was part of the RAF Bishopscourt complex and a key feature of the UKrsquos air defence network until its eventual closure in .lsquoThe Little Sisters of Jesus in Northern Ireland: The First  Years -, is an article by Jocelyne, Emiko and Helene, of the Little Sisters of Jesus, who have just recently relocated from Bishopscourt to Belfast. Their story tells us a little about community members and explains their decision to finally relocate to Belfast.Also included in this years edition is a reproduction of a Kilclief Gaelic Athletic Club souvenir programme from , which includes addresses to Raymond McConville and to Carmel Reid, who achieved success withthe Down Gaelic football and camogie teams.Inverbrena Local History Group would be delighted to welcome members. The group meets on the third Friday of each month in the Inverbrena Hall in Strangford at pm. Those who are unable to commit to attending the monthly meetings are invited to contribute articles or photographs to future publications.Memories From Inverbrena: Strangford  can be purchased from Kevin Ogrsquos shop in Strangford, priced pound, or by contacting the group directly at inverbrena@hotmail.prettyPhoto

title: Delamont upgrade plans to receive £250k funding lift
story: PLANS to revitalise Delamont Country Park have are to receive a pound, boost.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is set to make the funding available to pave the way for work to start on the first phase of an ambitious programme to make the stunning facility on the shores of Strangford Lough even better.A new visitor centre is among a list of exciting proposals designed to help with the regenerationof the park which will take place over the next five years and beyond as part of an exciting new vision entitled lsquoWindow to Strangford Loughrsquo.This week, members of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee agreed to ask for pound, to be included in next yearrsquos budget to kick-start Delamontrsquos redevelopment.In addition, the local authority will also be examining other potential funding opportunities to finance the proposed work designed to copper-fasten Delamontrsquos position as a standout location where people come and interact with the picturesque waterway and embrace the stunning environment.The proposals which feature in the blueprint aim to maximise Delamontrsquos strategic location on the shores of the internationally acclaimed waterway.Initial work includes transforming the way in which information on the -acre park is interpreted for visitors highlighting its wildle, flora and fauna, park events and its links with Strangford Lough.This work also aims to better communicate the history and heritage of the country park and increasing accessibility around the picturesque trail network to improve access to key features and locations.The use of audio technology is also planned alongside the potential to expand the current adventure playground and caravan park and there are also plans to provide a new disabled parking area along the shoreline.Other proposals include enhancing the walled garden area and the parkrsquos pond, with suggestions that community allotments could also be developed for the use of local people and Killyleagh Gardening Club.Local politicians have welcomed the phased approach to development which includes maximising the dedicated viewing area over Strangford Lough via an enhanced  and are excited at what the future holds.Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews said a phased approach to redevelopment is necessary and in addition to local authority funding, he hopes that finance can be secured from external funders.He continued: ldquoA sustainable approach to redevelopment is being adopted to maximise Delamontrsquos signicant potential. The public has had its chance to have a say in what happens at the country park and two weeks ago was given an opportunity to look at what is envisaged moving forward.ldquoThe ious proposals will help transform the country park and increase the already particularly impressive visitor figures. The feedback from the planned way forward has been positive and these are exciting times for Delamont.Cllr Andrews mdash who spends what spare time he has walking around the park mdash paid tribute to all those involved in the work to move the redevelopment proposals to the stage where work can start soon on implementation.He added: ldquoAs I have said many times, Delamont is one of the many jewels in the districtrsquos tourism crown and we are very fortunate to have it. Great credit must go to the former Down Council which took the bold step many years ago to purchase what has become a brilliant facility and one set to get even better.ldquoDelamont is as a wonderful park located in a spectacular location. The plans are welcome and I hope that they will pave the way for more visitors coming to the park out-of-season..prettyPhoto

title: Down hopes as secretary maps out future
story: DOWN GAArsquos annual county convention takes place in the Canal Court Hotel, Newry, tonight.Delegates will hear county secretary Sean Og McAteer deliver a wide-ranging report that reflects on the past year and looks ahead to the future with optimism, particularly in relation to the proposed centre of excellence in Ballykinlar.The county secretary believes that the project to develop a county training facility is an initiative to be positive about and he hopes that planning permission will be achieved shortly.In his annual report Mr McAteer accepts that  has been a frustrating season in terms of success at county level and pulls no punches when it come to some of the more controversial moments of the year.ldquoOur county teams are our shop window, the performance of our county teams is how people measure the performance of the GAA in Down,` he says.Promotion in football and hurling in  has to be a requirement, he insists, and administrators must put in place an environment for success both on and off the field.ldquoAfter that it is up to players and management. In  we have to deliver in terms of promotion from Division  of the Football League and from Division B of the Hurling League.Mr McAteer also turns his attention to some of the more unsavoury moments of , including an incident at Pairc Esler when a player was abused from the stand with family members close by. ldquoIn the summer of , I think our moral compass went off in a dferent direction and showed a very dferent side of how we should treat people, he says.ldquoRespect for the person sitting beside you or in front of you at a club game went out the window as emotion and passion were channelled in a negative direction.ldquoI feel that we need toto the values that helped make our association the great body that it is, and which sets us apart as not just a sporting body, but the cultural heartbeat of a nation, he will say.Mr McAteer also pays a personal tribute to former Down manager and double All-Ireland winner Eamonn Burns, who died in October.ldquoEamonn will be best remembered as midfielder on the All-Ireland-winning team of . Down fans will remember Eamonnrsquos two points from play in that win over Meath as Sam Maguire ed North for the first time in  years, he says.ldquoIn  Eamonn was once again to the fore this time at right half back on the team that defeated Dublin playing through the pain barrier to ensure that his beloved Down made it five All-Ireland titles.ldquoAfter his distinguished playing career with both club and county, Eamonn took on coaching and managerial roles guiding Bryansford to a Down Senior Championship success. In  when Jim McCorry had resigned as Down senior football team manager, Eamonn stepped up to the mark and took on the role of county senior football team manager.Mr McAteer adds: ldquoDown GAA have been privileged to have Eamonn Burns amongst our sons. He gave us as supporters many magical moments, and he brought a smile to our faces and in those days of  and  he helped bring us the glory days again..prettyPhoto

title: Down Parish Church opens doors for annual Christmas crib festival
story: DOWN Parish Church opened the doors to its annual Christmas crib festival yesterday morning.The event mdash now in its third year mdash features a wide and ied display of nativity scenes created by a number of organisations including churches, charities, schools and groups.The festival at the Downpatrick church is open daily between am and .pm until Friday and there will also be an opportunity to view the displays this Saturday between am and .pm.Many people took the time during the busy festive period last year tointo the church to marvel at the displays and have a cup of tea or coffee and a chat and organisers have issued an open invitation to people to call in this year.Organisers are also hoping that representatives from local businesses will take time to view the displays made by representatives from the Fountain Foodbank, Downpatrick Primary School, Downpatrick Nursery School, Downpatrick Womenrsquos Institute, Down Parish Church, Youth Initiatives, Downpatrick Girlsrsquo Brigade and Cloughrsquos Cumran Primary School.The Pepper Johns Ladies Group which meets every Wednesday morning in Downpatrick has made a special piece of artwork for the festival.Down Parish Church minister, the Rev Captain Scott McDonald, says he has been delighted with the response to the innovative festival since its launch and is hoping that the event will prove equally popular this year.He said that it has been ldquowonderful over the past few years to witness the creative talents of all those who took the time to come up with a wide range of designs.Describing many of the creations as ldquooriginal and thought provoking Mr McDonald is grateful to all those who continue to support the event, either by making their own cribs or visiting the church to view those on display.Mr McDonald continued: ldquoThis will be our third festival and we have been fortunate to have had the support of so many people over the past two years.ldquoThe ious displays have been made by a iety of groups asked to design a crib which reflects the Christmas story and also elements of their work, looking at Christmas through a fresh pair of eyes.Mr McDonald said the festival is designed to draw people in from their busy schedule at this time of the year to have a look at the ious displays and take time to reflect on the message of Christmas.Mrs Alison Carson mdash who is also heavily involved in the project mdash said there are a number of festivals at this time of year, with some churches across the district focusing on Christmas tree displays.She added: ldquoThe crib festival provides an opportunity for a wide range of groups to get involved and do something a little dferent at this special time of year which, for many, represents a period of reflection..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C December 11%2C 1979
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash Downtown Radio disc jockey Hendi switched on the Christmas tree lights at Ballynahinch Square on Friday evening in front of almost one thousand people.The townspeople had gathered in their hundreds to see the official switch-on and the presence of cartoon characters, Ballynahinch Silver Band and the choirs from several local schools added to the occasion.The new pound, Christmas lanterns had been on view earlier since the street lighting went on and with the townrsquos shops open for late night shopping, the scene was set for a night to remember.Mr W Irwin, chairman of Ballynahinch Chamber of Commerce, which had been the driving force behind the new lighting scheme, introduced Hendi and Mr Redvers Garnham introduced the ious items, including the short programme of carols by the choir from Assumption Grammar School, Ballynahinch High School and St Colmanrsquos High School, accompanied by Ballynahinch Silver Band.The children were amused by the arrival of cartoon characters Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck, who mingled with the crowd. Hundreds of free balloons were distributed and a liberal quantity of free lemonade, donated by Cantrell and Cochrane, was handed out.The nightrsquos activities were organised by the Chamber of Commerce to launch their Christmas shopping drive. With the help of a grant from Down Council and a share of the Swimming Pool Project Fund, most of the traders of the town had given generously in response to the Chamberrsquos plea to reach the pound, target needed to purchase the new lanterns for the lighting scheme.ARDGLASS mdash Sub aqua ers are hunting for a Norwegian gun-running ship which sank off the Ardglass coast, carrying with it a number of cannons.However, members of the Craigavon Sub Aqua Club are being thwarted in the search because they have been unable to pinpoint the exact spot where the vessel went down.One of the members said: ldquoOn three occasions we were shown dferent locations by people claiming to know where the ship went down,but each time our drivers found nothing.The club members are still keen on ing for the vessel and they are appealing to anyone who may know where it is lying to contact them.Last week several club members found a heavy anchor at Bangor, which could be as much as  years old, but they have now reached a point where they are running short of ing sites.NEWCASTLE mdash Newcastle Technical Collegersquos hopes of making extensive use of facilities at the former factory on the townrsquos Castlewellan Road have been severely hampered by the massive cutbacks in government expenditure.The collegersquos principal, Mr James Ellis, told guests, parents and pupils at the annual presentation of certicates that the cutbacks mean work may not be carried out until early next year.Mr Ellis also spoke of other dficulties caused by cutbacks. These included the non-replacement of clerical staff who resign and y delays in the supply of equipment necessary for class use.Mr Ellis also slammed a proposal to impose a charge for school transport and labelled it as ldquoclearly unfair.He stressed that he was not taking the negative attitude that all cuts are bad. Extravagance should be eliminated, he said, but the sudden imposition of cash limits had placed education boards in an impossible position at a time of high inflation.DOWNPATRICK mdash A  year-old Downpatrick school teacher has won national poetry competition which attracted , entries.Mrs Maeve McGuckian, of Springvale Drive, who teaches English at St Patrickrsquos College, Knock, won the top prize of pound in a competition which was organised by BBCrsquos Poetry Society.Her winning poem, entitled lsquoThe Flittingrsquo, is a lyrical look at le. Maeve has been writing poems since she left school and has had several published in magazines.Maeve entered the competition in its inaugural year, in , but wasnrsquot placed mdash so she was stunned to find she had won it outright this time.She was interviewed on BBC on Friday and received her award from Robert Robinson.CASTLEWELLAN mdash  A legally held shotgun and a Colt Celeste car were stolen last Thursday when three armed and masked men burst into a Castlewellan house.The men entered the house in Bunkers Hill and after demanding the shotgun and the keys they made off in the car, which was found the next morning blocking a lane near Bryansford. An army technical officer was called, but nothing was found.COMBER mdash Comber is to get a massive new pound, recreation and community centre and work is expected to begin early next year.Final plans for the scheme, which will include a community hall, were given the stamp of approval by Ards Borough Council this week. The blueprint now goes to the Department of Education for approval.The centre will be located at the rear of Castle Street and is intended to put a new heart back into the town. The council are expected to apply for a vesting order for some of the land needed.Mr John McKnight, the councilrsquos assistant recreation officer, said he was ldquodelighted to see the scheme going ahead.ldquoThis scheme will go a long way to meeting the lack of recreational facilities in the town, he said.He felt the facilities would prove popular and said he was pleased that the area could become a top spot for sporting activity.SHRIGLEY mdash The Kampuchea Relief Fund got a welcome boost this week from an unlikely source mdash the savings accounts of employees at a local factory.The money came from members of the Ulster Leather Company at Shrigley and instead of using the pound they had saved up for their holidays they decided instead to give it to people in the country formerly known as Cambodia.The Killyleagh and Shrigley Friendship Club and the De La Salle boysrsquo home at Kircubbin will also benefit from the gesture.TYRELLA mdash Pupils at Tyrella Primary School have raised pound. for the Blue Peter Cambodia Appeal Fund. The pupils raised the money from a monster sale in the school on Saturday, which was attended by Santa.BALLYCRUTTLE mdash A special disco organised by Ballycruttle Youth Club has raised pound for the Blue Peter Cambodia Appeal Fund. The disco was held in the club premises and the music was provided free of charge by Double K Disco.CROSSGAR mdash Crossgar are the new Down Boysrsquo Brigade Battalion volleyball champions. The Crossgar company defeated st Downpatrick in a repeat of last yearrsquos final and so gained revenge for that defeat. st Killinchy were third and st Drumgooland fourth.The finals were held in Dromore High School and the standard was high throughout. Both Crossgar and Downpatrick will represent Down Battalion in the Northern Ireland heats.KILLINCHY mdash Over  members of Killinchy Womenrsquos Institute were in festive mood when they met for their Christmas party in the Bishop Hall.The president, Mrs Ann Savage, welcomed all present who then enjoyed a delicious fork supper prepared by Mr Thomas Newell, a young Killinchy man, who has recently commenced an outside catering venture.BALLYWALTER mdash Plans for a fete at the house and grounds of Lord and Lady Dunleath at Ballywalter have been announced.The fete is to be organised by the Church Missionary Society of Ireland and the proceeds will go to help in the Third World..prettyPhoto

title: Group praises founder Monica who helps give pets new home
story: A TEAM of animal lovers who run a pet rescue page on social media have come together to highlight its overwhelming success.The group have rehabilitated and re-homed hundreds of pets since the Lost Found Pets South Down page went live on Facebook over two years ago.They say thatit wasnrsquot for the tireless work of its founder Monica McDonald, from Ballynagross, outside Downpatrick, many pets would remain lost or uncared for.Never one to seek the limelight, Monica was eager to point out that the success of the page relies, not on anything that she has done, but on the great team of volunteers connected with thenot-for-profit organisation.Monica says usually their work involves helping puppies or kittens, but they have also come to the rescue of an otter, a ferret, a handful of hamsters and even a snake.It was Monicarsquos successful search for Herky, a feisty two year-old pug-cross, that heralded the beginning of the group.The dog went missing in Church Street, Downpatrick, but was found and reunited with his owner three days later following a Facebook appeal.Shortly after this, a dirty Samoyed dog arrived with Monica one evening.Monica said: ldquoWe called him Sony. He was very young and had been badly neglected. He had been kept in a confined space or a very small pen. Sony was very loving. All he wanted was to be loved and he thrived on attention.ldquoHe was a huge dog but very dirty. When we gave him a bath his coat came up lovely and white. We got him started with his first round of vaccinations and our followers stood by us financially.Monica works closely with Corran Kennels, on the Tobercorran Road outside Downpatrick, who come to her for helpthey need a puppy or dog re-homed, and Animal Connexions, based at Nutts Corner outside Belfast.Monica said: ldquoRecently a litter of  kittens were about to be euthanised and we managed to be able to find homes for all of them within a short period of time.Monica added that she has her own account with the two branches of Castle Vets in Downpatrick and Castlewellan and pays for any necessary medical attention abandoned pets may need out of her own pocket.ldquoMembers of the public are so good. When we put up an appeal on the page that an animal requires surgery or medicine they phone the vets and give money and it comes off the bill.ldquoI am so grateful to everyone. It can be tough going and running something like this takes a big chunk out of your le, but our team of volunteers are thankfully very enthusiastic.ldquoAnyone can follow the page. Just ask to join the group through the socialmedia network and followers will be able to keep up-to-date with what we are doing.Lana King, from Burrenreagh, is a volunteer with the not-for-profit organisation.She said: ldquoWhile the main aim of the page back in  originally was to reunite owners with their pets, there are times when nobody comes looking for a little lost one and thatrsquos when Monica goes beyond the call of duty and ensures they have a second chance with a new family.ldquoShe gets to know the potential owner, carries out a home check and follows it up. There is nothing she loves more than to hear how the pets she has helped to re-home or re-habilitate are doing.Lana added: ldquoMonica really is the back bone of Lost Found Pets South Down and has gained the admiration and respect from anyone who comes into contact with her.ldquoNothing is ever too much bother for her.ldquoShe has devoted her le to animals and makes sure every pet that comes to her receives the very best of care.ldquoEven though Monica suffers with a debilitating disease called lupus, she just gets up every morning and gets on with it.ldquoHer sharp wit, sense of humour and contagious laugh lts the spirits of people who are going through the heartbreak of having their pet go missing and reassures them because they know Monica will do everything she can to reunite them with their beloved pet.Lana added: ldquoMonica helps those pets who have found themselves either lost, abandoned, abused or simply not having a loving home to call their own..prettyPhoto

title: Health workers take  industrial strike action
story: HEALTH workers in Downpatrick took strike action last Friday ahead of a series of protests calling for pay parity and adequate nursing numbers.Nurses were working to rule yesterday and today at the Downshire and Downe Hospitals while a joint strike planned between their union, the Royal College of Nursing , and Unison, will be held next Wednesday.Hospital and outlying district services will be impacted as the strike will run from am until pm mdash unless a deal is done before that.Unison and the RCN are demanding equal pay for its members in line with UK counterparts and for increased nurse recruitment to protect patients in a failing health service.Domestics, porters, catering staff, administrative staff, dental nurses from all wards and departments in the Downe and Downshire Hospitals and outlying facilities will join nurses who have voted to strike for the first time in their -year history.Public support was high for health workers, including nurses from the Down Outpatients Department, who took part in Fridayrsquos strike.Hundreds of Unison members joined the picket in the morning and afternoon at Downshire Hospitalrsquos entrance with local drivers sounding support as they passed.The impact of the action closed the Outpatients department at the Downe Hospital, along with the Ulster Hospital, Lagan Valley, Ards and Bangor Hospitals.The Community Dental Service was impacted with the cancellation of the Ballynahinch clinic and two clinics at Downe Hospital on Friday afternoon.The impact was widespread for patients as day case surgery, ENT and gynaecology at Lagan Valley Hospital was cancelled along with the closure of the Medical Day Case Unit, Dermatology Laser Unit, Cath Lab and Ambulatory Hubs at the Ulster Hospital.The South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust said that that all affected patients had been contacted and would be rescheduled for appointments at a future date.Staff from the Downshire Hospital were strengthened by colleagues from the nearby Downe, who joined the picket.Unison members who work in the transport and domiciliary care went out on strike from am- noon while the rest of the workers came out from pm-pm.South Down MP Chris Hazzard and SDLP election candidate Michael Savage showed their support as did SDLP MLA Colin McGrath and Downpatrick councillors Oonagh Hanlon and John Trainor.Unison branch secretary Marian Ritchie called on all the elected representatives present to give members more than a show of support.She told cheering strikers: ldquoWe want every politician here now to give a commitment to say, as iniduals and as a group, that every single one of the the health service staff will get a pay rise and pay parity.The call was met with shouts of ldquoGet back to work by the strikers.Ms Ritchie also told her colleagues: ldquoThe Permanent Secretary says that he has the money but not the authority and the only ones that have the authority are the politicians. Thatrsquos why we asking the politicians to write to the Permanent Secretary today and give us what we want, thatrsquos pay parity.She estimated that between -% of her members turned out to strike and represented nurses, mental health workers, occupational therapists, dental nurses, domiciliary care and administrative workers from both hospitals.When asked about the potential impact that the full day strike would have on patients, Mrs Ritchie answered: ldquoWe are hoping that the Secretary of State and the Permanent secretary will see sense before that. We are not asking for anything we are not entitled to.Mr Eamonn McGrady, chairman of Down Community Health Committee, and one of its members, Mrs Anne Trainor, also attended the picket to show their support.Mr McGrady said that the committee was ldquofully behind the staff members and promised that it would continue to back their campaign.Mrs Trainor explained why she was on the picket and said: ldquoMy role is to represent the community and I have been sounding out people in the town today and they say they are % behind the nurses and the ancillary staff who have been so unequally paid over a long number of years in comparison to the mainland.ldquoOver the years of the Troubles these people held this country together and nowhere  in the country did this happen and that has been acknowledged. We need equality and equity immediately.When asked about prolonged impact of strike action on patients, Mrs Trainor added: ldquoI think that Stormont will bend quicker than we will. We have been fighting for services in this local hospital for the last  years. We are not going away.A Health and Social Care spokesperson said: ldquoAll Health and Social Care organisations will continue to work closely together to mitigate the effects of any disruption from industrial action with a strong focus on patient safety.ldquoWe apologise for the stress and anxiety caused to all those patients, clients and family members who have been and may be affected.For the latest and most up to date information on disruptions and cancellations visit www.setrust.hscni.net or www.hscboard.hscni.net hsc-industrial-action-updates..prettyPhoto

title: Kelly eyeing up more sporting qualifications
story: ANNACLOY teenager Hannah Kelly recently qualied in the IFArsquos Grassroots Introductory Award.The  year-old St Colmcillersquos High School pupil has a keen interest in sport and aims to achieve more qualications as she seeks her pathway in le.The Year  student is a dedicated Liverpool fan and is certainly ahead of the game as she is keen to seek out other sporting opportunities.She is part of the Teconnaught girlsrsquo GAA team and also plays for both her schoolrsquos soccer and Gaelic football teams.The Crossgar school is currently one of the top sporting institutions in the district as it promotes, coaches and attends all local sporting events with their students.The driving force behind the schoolrsquos sporting achievements is enthusiastic PE teacher, Susan McMullan, who understands the importance of sporting activities.ldquoNot only is it my job, but I believe it is vital that my students avail of all the sporting opportunities that we can accept as the outcomes of sport are endless, she said.ldquoI want our students leaving our school having experienced a wide iety of sporting experiences through practical participation and qualications as the benefits of health, mental, social and friendships is so evident.The quietly confident Hannah certainly doesnrsquot wait for opportunities to fall on her lap as she sources out where she wants to go.ldquoI suppose, coming from a family where sport is played and spoken about most days, it is only natural that I may go down that routeI decide too, she enthused.ldquoThe next stage of my own personal development will be attending my work experience next March with local soccer coach Seamus Heath and I am already looking forward to shadowing him and learning how football development works.Seamus said: ldquoI feel strongly that it is our duty to help, advise and assist our young people,we can, as sporting participation can be a le-long experiencewe treat it properly and provide proper opportunities.For further information contact Seamus at sheath@irishfa or call  ..prettyPhoto

title: Oisin boxes clever to win novice title
story: OISIN Morgan, who boxes for Bryansford ABC, recently reached the semi-finals of Ulster  County Novice tournament and also won the Louth Novice Open final.In the Ulster  County Novice, Oisin won his quarter final with style, in a classy, hit-move boxing performance.Oisinrsquos opponent kept the pressure on right until the end, but was no match for his speed and skill as the Bryansford teenager cruised to victory on a unanimous decision.Unfortunately, the semi-final was a dferent story. Despite a gutsy performance, he was unable to deal with his opponentrsquos height and range advantage.He accepted the loss with grace and ed to the drawing board in preparation for Louth.The Louth Open Novice final saw Oisin battle it out with an equally hungry competitor.The two were well matched in size and style. Oisin kept his opponent on the back foot as he stalked him for the entire three rounds.Both fighters engaged in heated exchanges, but Oisin was able to maintain his composure, controlling the range and landing more frequent eye-catching shots.Credit to Oisinrsquos opponent, who continually forced him back and on occasions successfully broke through his defence.This was met with a quick response from Oisin, re-establishing his control. The result from the judges was a split decision, giving Oisin the win.This is his last competition as a novice. We look forward to see him on a bigger stage next season..prettyPhoto

title: Ross roasts rivals with divine treble
story: A RAVENOUS Killough side rekindled their love affair with the NFU Bobby Dalzell Cup at Binnian Park on Friday night when they blitzed Ballynagross with an irresistible display.Ballynahinch Olympic Town are now standing in Killoughrsquos way of bringing Bobby home and their fate will be decided in the Boxing Day showdown at Meadowvale.The Mountain Quarter side were left battered, bruised and bewildered as the voracious Killough mob raced into an unassailable - interval lead.A mixture of Ballynagross tightening things up all over the park in the second half and Killoughrsquos waning interest, ensured that there was only one goal scored after the break with Conor Marron netting a consolation from the penalty spot.Killough showed their intent from early on as they closed Ballynagross down like a pack of bounty hunters chasing their prey.Tony McIlhone, Adam George, Matt McKiernan and Gareth George bossed the middle of the park with a high press.They refused to give Ballynagross time on the ball and with all four operating from a central position and then spreading out to close the player of the ball down, there was no time for Philip Campbellrsquos beleaguered troops to settle.With just two minutes gone Killough struck. McIlhone won the ball off a Ballynagross defender and without even looking up let one fly from  yards out.Goalkeeper Ross Preece was stranded in no manrsquos land and his despairing outstretched attempt to tip the ball over the crossbar failed as the ball nestled in the back of the net.Two minutes later, man of the match Ross Armstrong made it -. He chased a lost cause of a ball into the box where Marron and Preece were favourites to win the race, but Armstrongrsquos sheer desire helped to get him to the ball first and he was able to dink it into an empty net.With  minutes gone Armstrong pounced again to make it - after McIlhone had carved out the opening.Killough continued to bombard Ballynagross with everything and anything, but Ballynagross bravely weathered the storm and gradually started to create chances of their own.With  minutes gone they patiently worked an opening for Ryan McKinney, but he was denied a goal when the impressive Sean Og Burns got back to hack the ball off the line.That was as good as it got for Ballynagross as Killough made it - three minutes later. Gareth George picked the ball up from a Ben McLaughlin throw and immediately set off on one of his trademark, penetrating runs.George had only one thing on his mind after leaving three players for dead and his unerring finish into the bottom corner had Preece clutching at thin air.Six minutes later it was - when Armstrong headed a free back across the box and McIlhone had all the time in the world to send Killough into delirium.With  minutes gone a delightful cross from Adam George was met perfectly by Armstrong and the big striker powered an unstoppable header to the net to make it -.Some of Killoughrsquos play in the first half was breathtaking and few teams could have lived with them and as the players trooped off at half-time, everyone feared for Ballynagross.However, the break gave Campbell the chance to reorganise his troops and the were a dferent proposition in the second half.Marron pulled one back from the spot after Sean Og Burns took down Philip Doran in the box, but despite creating several other chances, that was it for Ballynagross.Eoin Rooney and Conor McCarron had shots well saved by Killough lsquokeeper Eddie Hinc, while Liam Graham headed over at the other end and Preece saved from Gareth George.Killough were a pale shadow of the side that lit up Binnian Park in the first  minutes, but they can be forgiven for taking their foot off the pedal after taking a - lead.Ballynagross can only reflect on what might have been, had they been able to field at full strength, but football can be a cruel game as they found out on Friday night.Killough: Eddie Hinc, Matthew Burns, Ben McLaughlin, Colm Stranney, Sean Og Burns, Matt McKiernan, Gareth George, Adam George, Tony McIlhone, Ross Armstrong, Riain Burns: Subs: Liam Graham, Seamas Tumelty, Ryan McIlhone, Robbie Hagan, Ruairi Sharvin.Ballynagross: Ross Preece, Deaglan Craig, Tom McNeill, Aaron Beattie, Conor Marron, Conor McCarron, Karl Johnston, Mark Magill, Daniel Taggart, Declan Dowie, Ryan McKinney. Subs: John Shields, Philip Doran, Eoin Rooney, Gareth Robinson, Cormac Byrne.Killough Ballynagross BOBBY DALZELL CUP SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde keep up rich vein of form
story: AT the halfway point of the season itrsquos tight at the top as only a half point separate the reigning champions Seaforde from their old foes from St Maryrsquos, Killyleagh mdash itrsquos going to be an interesting second half to see who comes out on top.A great battle is developing for third spot between Marina and Loughinisland with the latter holding a . point lead. The Islanders have really surprised everyone this year as they make a greatto the top ision.Down at the other end of the table its looking like Drumaroad will be heading to relegation unless their fortunes change dramatically, the other place will be fought between Kilmegan and Bright with just a point and a half between them.St Michaelrsquos, Dundrum and St Patrickrsquos Golf Club should be safe in mid-table, but the Golfers have really taken a turn for the worse and are struggling to pick up points, so might find themselves in a relegation fight.DRUMAROAD.SEAFORDE YFC.SEAFORDE made the short trip to the lsquoFin to play a home side still looking for their first win of the season and came away with a good haul of points to keep their lead at the top of the table.A half decent start for the home side as the rinks of Joe Scullion and David Boal finished in a - draw. On the other mat Graham Christiersquos rink of Robert Shaw, Trevor Perry and Kirsty Burns had a good - win over Thomas Walsh for the visitors.The next two games were tight affairs as Hugh Burns held on a - win against Kevin Walsh while the home four of Liam Dummigan, Maire Scullion, Adrian Mussen and Harry Addis scored a single on the last end against Peter Christie for a - win.After tea the visitors took control of the match with a clean sweep of wins with Graham Christie doubling up with a - win over the Addis four and David Boal leading his rink of Alan Bleue, Joy Perry and Paddy Burns to a - win against Kevin Walsh.The rinks of Peter Christie and Hugh Burns wrapped the match up for Seaforde with wins of - and -.KILMEGAN.ST MARYrsquoS, KILLYLEAGH.THE Saints made the trip to Castlewellan knowing they needed a good result to stay with the league leaders Seaforde after their good win earlier in the week and they managed to match their rivals to keep it tight at the top.Ricky Cathcart and his rink of Liz Murray, Stevie Brown and Keiran McMullan got the challenge off to a great start by not losing an end for a - win over Micky Keown.On the other mat Paddy Murray was having a great tussle against Don Corrigan and his rink of Jean King, Rose McAllister and Hugh McCann, who scored seven shots on the third end, but just lost out - to the visitors.Another two big wins for the visitors on the next run as Neil Brown and Tony Ward also racked up double figure wins of - and - against Brendan Corrigan and Noreen Magorrian to go into the break with a  shot advantage. After tea the home Magorrian four secured a low scoring draw of - against the Murray rink and the away Cathcart secured another good win of - over Brendan Corrigan.The final run of games would end up being shared as the Brown four got another away point with a - win over the Keown rink, but credit to the rink skipped by Don Corrigan as they won the last end for a - win over the away Ward rink to secure a win and draw for this Kilmegan four.BRIGHT.ST PATRICKrsquoS GC.THE home side took full advantage of an understrength Golf Club side who arrived with only the minimum  players, so were always losing a quarter of their shots total.The match actually started well for the visitors as Laurence Craig, Ernie Kenmore and David Gibson ended up with a - win over Niall Polley.Hugh Porter and his rink of Raymond Kearney, Linda Cherry and Sean Deegan hit back with a -. win against Teresa Powell. The Golfers came out better on the next run as Liam Higgins had a .- win over Andy Campbell, while the rinks of Liam Sharvin and Alan Telford finished in a - draw.After tea the two games were shared with a -. win for the home Sharvin four and an away win for David Gibson of .- to secure his double.Bright won the match in the final two games as Hugh Porter doubled up with a -. win and Niall Polley finished the match off with a - win to take the overall score.The other match in the ision saw Marina travel to surprise package Loughinisland and it was the Islanders who came out on top with a .-. points win, which moved them ahead of their visitors into third position in the table..prettyPhoto

title: Security firm policing council’s new facility without electricity
story: A PRIVATE security firm has been employed to police Downpatrickrsquos new poundm household recycling centre.The Flying Horse Road facility mdash which opened in October mdash has no mains electricity to power the ultra-modern sitersquos high-tech security system, rendering it inoperable.As a result, the local authority is paying for a private security firm to police the centre outside its normal operating hours, but is refusing to say how much this is costing ratepayers whoare also footing the bill for the hire of a generator.It has been installed to supply electricity at the centre to power lights, staff accommodation and some specialised skips and containers which are capable of compacting materials, including cardboard.Council officials have confirmed that the power supplied by the generator is not adequate to run the Flying Horse Road centrersquos CCTV cameras which are dotted around the site, but hopes to have mains power installed as soon as possible.Over recent years, signicant sums have been invested in new civic amenity sites in Ballynahinch and Castlewellan, with the Flying Horse Road facility described as one of the most modern of its kind.It opened amid a blaze of publicity and coincided with confirmation that the amount of waste being recycled locally is above the Northern Ireland target with the Newry, Mourne and Down area now one of the provincersquos top recycling authorities.The district is recycling just over % of its waste and has passed the Northern Ireland average for the first time. Over the past year, the level of recycled waste has increased by %.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran hopes the work to provide mains power to the new Flying Horse Road facility is completed as soon as possible.ldquoI do not know why there is no mains power but it is a little embarrassing that the CCTV cameras at a poundm centre cannot be operated and we have had to hire in a private security firm, he said.ldquoThis represents an additional cost to already hard-pressed ratepayers and I hope that we are talking about days, not weeks, for the mains power to be supplied. It is an issue council officers need to be on top of.Cllr Curran said that many people were keen to see the new centre opened, given that its predecessor at nearby Cloonagh Road was struggling to cope with the huge demand being placed upon it.He continued: ldquoIt is great to have such a modern recycling facility on our doorstep to meet the needs of people who are clearly recycling their waste in increasing numbers. The new centre is being well used and the council deserves credit for this major investment but, in my opinion, the mains power issue should have been sorted before it opened for business.Cllr Curran said that given the increased emphasis on recycling, the council is behind innovative plans to allow groups and charities across the district to reuse ious items dumped at household recycling centres in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch.He added: ldquoA number of groups have expressed an interest in taking part and I have no doubt that this scheme will be a success with ious items destined for the scrapheap given a new lease of le.A council spokeswoman confirmed that the recycling centre was operating without mains power.ldquoIt has taken longer than anticipated to connect the mains power supply at the new site, said the spokeswoman.ldquoAs a temporary measure, a generator and security firm are being used to cover requirements. Newry, Mourne and Down Council is working to have the mains power installed as soon as possible.The Recorder asked the local authority how much it is paying the security firm to police the new civic amenity site outside its normal operating hours but was not provided with an answer..prettyPhoto

title: Sr Bartholomew’s centenary celebrations
story: THE family of a Leitrim nun, who has lived in Africa for  years, flew thousands of miles to help her celebrate her  birthday.Sr Mary Bartholomew was joined by five nieces, including Dympna Kelly and Eileen Ramsey from her home village, who arrived in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, to mark her milestone birthday last week.Another niece, Mary McAleenan, from Slievnaboley, near Leitrim, who wasnrsquot able to make the journey, says her aunt had been on an adventure since she left home in  on board the Warwick Castle to care for ldquothe poorest of the poor amid the soaring heat of South Africa.Sr Bartholmew, was born Philomena Cunningham on December , , and enjoyed growing up with her four sisters and three brothers on what is now known as Kilnhill Road in Leitrim.She and her older sister, Mary Bernadette, who also became a nun, were among the first girls to play camogie in Leitrim before an official team had even been set up by the local Fontenoys GAA club.She was educated at Sacred Heart Grammar School in Newry and with her heart set on a religious vocation she entered the Assumption Convent in Ballynahinch just as World War II began.Her niece, Mary, said that being a nun in those days brought honour to a family and having two daughters as nuns set the Cunninghams apart within their small rural village.ldquoThere were nine other postulants accompanying Sr Bartholomew on the long voyage across to Africa. Her ship was the last passenger ship to sail to the continent for many years, as most ships were then commissioned for the war effort, Mary explained.The young nun swapped the green fields and rain of home for the blistering heat and bustle of Grahamstown in the Eastern Cape, which must have been quite an experience.She completed her religious formation and academic teacher training before taking her vows in . Over the following decades she taught in several schools. Eventually, on retiring, she was assigned a new mission, opening a clinic and a pre-school within an encampment that catered for over , refugees fleeing the horrors of the Mozambique war.In Sr Bartholomewrsquos own words of this period in her le, recorded in a book written over  years ago, Drumgooland ndash A Parish Divided, she recalls: ldquoWith missionary zeal we did our utmost over the following years to render whatever assistance we could to the many thousands of refugees, I taught including adults.ldquoThese poor people had a minimum of education and were eager to learn English. After class we would sit around and read the bible in Shangaan, the local language, and gave help when it was needed.Niece Mary takes up the story again. She added: ldquoNuns donrsquot retire and while Sr Bartholomew found the intense heat too much after several years, she made for the cooler environment of an office and spent time in general admin.Sr Bartholomew would often make the trip back home to Leitrim after Vatican II came to pass when the rigours and discipline of a pious le became more relaxed in the s. However, she was always looked forward to going back to Port Elizabeth.Her last trip home was some years ago when her older sister, Eileen, was seriously ill.ldquoShe had managed to hold her hand and chat briefly before she passed away, Mary recalled. She stayed until Eileenrsquos months mind,and left shortly after. This was the last time she was home..prettyPhoto

title: Teenager Sophie fundraising for blind charity
story: A BALLYNAHINCH teenager has embarked upon a fundraising initiative on behalf of the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association.Sophie Millswill be selling raffle tickets for a host of prizes over the coming weeks ahead of a a key fundraising event in Ballynahinch Masonic Hall on February  next year.The Year  Ballynahinch High School student mdash who has been diagnosed with Albinism mdash is on the waiting list for a guide dog and has already been cane-trained by representatives from the charity.The teenager, who relies on the aid of her cane, is hoping that she will get her guide dog sometime next year, but is conscious that there is a long waiting list.Sophie, who recently finished in the top six of a SuperValu Superstars competition and was presented with a certicate during a glittering awards night at Belfastrsquos Titanic Hotel, is keen to help the Guide Dogs charity by raising money on its behalf.Her mum Marina said the estimated cost of training a guide dog is pound,.She explained: ldquoSophie wants to raise as much money as she can to help the charity which does not receive any government funding. It is her way of giving something back to an organisation which is helping her and so many others.ldquoSophie studies at Ballynahinch High School with the help of a classroom assistant and is keen to raise as much as she can.Her mum said that a number of local businesses have been very generous in offering raffle prizes and she hopes that others will kindly donate some more.Marina added: ldquoAn evening of live music gets underway at .pm and the entry fee is pound. The winners of the raffle will be drawn on the night and Sophie hopes the evening will be a success..prettyPhoto

title: Tourism centre future talks put back to New Year
story: DISCUSSIONS on the future of Downpatrickrsquos visitor information centre are to be held early in the New Year.It was widely expected that talks about the future of the dedicated centre would have been held on Monday evening, but the matter did not feature on the agenda of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and TourismCommittee meeting.As exclusively revealed in the Recorder last month, Downpatrick could lose its dedicated visitor information centre under radical proposals being considered by the local authority.The issue was briefly debated during a behind-closed-doors meeting of the councilrsquos ERT Committee in Newry last month, with the matter again raised at last weekrsquos meeting of the full council by Downpatrick councillor Cadogan Enright.He criticised the local authority for agreeing to hold discussions on the future of the visitor facility mdash located at the St Patrick Centre mdash in secret.While no formal decision has yet been made, the Recorder understands that council officers are considering ending the dedicated presence of staff in their current base at the St Patrick Centre in the town.Council officials have confirmed that a report which considered the future opportunities for visitor information centres within the district was tabled for discussion in November, with the meeting held in committee and no final decision made.It is understood that there had been no consultation with local politicians about the future of the visitor information centres prior to last monthrsquos proposal being discussed.Last week, the council chief executive, Mrs Marie Ward, explained that as the visitor information centre issue debated by the ERT committee fell under a section of the local government act in relation to financial or business affairs, it was not for public discussion.She added: ldquoAs staff are involved I think it important to make it clear that there is no proposal to close the visitor information centre in Downpatrick. The matter will be discussed at the next ERT Committee..prettyPhoto

title: Traders’ interest in shop front scheme
story: FIFTEEN traders have expressed an interest in taking part in a pound, scheme aimed at revitalising shop fronts at Irish Street in Downpatrick.The new scheme mdash which is being spearheaded by Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Communities mdash follows the completion earlier this year of a protracted public realm initiative.A number of formal planning applications paving the way for the work to start have been lodged recently.Scheduled to last three months, the pound, scheme took six months to complete due to a series of issues including the discovery of asbestos piping and problems with a sewer. Contractors also encountered problems with the foundations of the old blast wall at the former PSNI station.The Department for Infrastructure, which managed the problem-ridden public realm scheme on behalf of the Department for Communities and Newry, Mourne and Down Council, admitted that the delay had had a ldquonegative impact on trading across the town.Government officials also conceded that more should have been done to keep the Downpatrick business community affected by the overrunning regeneration project better informed.Confirmation that  traders have expressed an interest in the revitalisation scheme was confirmed at this weekrsquos meeting of the local councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.A steering group has been established to oversee the scheme and will work alongside an architect and quantity surveyor to deliver the project.News of the interest in the revitalisation scheme comes ahead of a planned meeting in the New Year to discuss the redevelopment of the former Irish Street police station site and a number of adjacent empty buildings.The meeting, which will be attended by council officials and representatives from a number of statutory agencies, is designed to provide traders with an opportunity to have their say on the ambitious retail and commercial proposal aimed at transforming the townrsquos economy.During the meeting, the discussion will help guide the development brief process aimed at paving the way for work on the multi-million pound plan to start.The development brief will outline what the local authority would like to see developed in Irish Street to maximise the potential of every square inch of available space, with permission recently secured to purchase an outstanding piece of ground close to the Irish Street car park to allow the ambitious proposal to proceed.When the blueprint for the future development of the site has been agreed, it will be advertised, inviting developers to come forward to transform the site to kick-start a signicant town centre economic regeneration initiative.Marks and Spencer and Home Bargains are reported to be interested in opening new premises in Downpatrick and view Irish Street as an ideal location as there are currently no other suitable sites available.Itrsquos now over two years since it was revealed that the former police station site had been earmarked for a major economic regeneration initiative which could potentially include new housing.The ambitious proposal has been described as the most signicant retail and commercial investment plan ever proposed for the town centre, with politicians hopeful that the plan to transform the sprawling town centre site as part of a major investment plan will provide a major boost for existing businesses.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran has welcomed news that  traders have expressed an interest in the Irish Street revitalisation scheme and is encouraging traders from across the town to take part in discussions on the future of the former police base site.He said it is critically important that the Downpatrick business community has an insight into helping shape the development brief for the biggest ever investment in the town centre.Cllr Curran added: ldquoIt is important that the business community grasps the opportunity it is being given to help shape the future development of a prominent town centre site. Traders must make their voices heard on a project which has the potential to rejuvenate the town centrersquos economy, providing a boost for existing businesses through increased footfall.ldquoI firmly believe that the planned redevelopment of the huge former police base site can attract additional retail investment in the heart of the town..prettyPhoto

title: Trevor to get locks snipped in aid of meningitis research
story: CROSSGAR man Trevor Simpson is having his flowing locks chopped on Christmas Eve to raise funds for the Meningitis Research Foundation.The fundraising haircut will take place in the villagersquos Corner Inn at .pm with the operation performed by Mrs Leta McConnell, owner of My-T-Sharp Barbers.Trevorrsquos fundraiser is his way of giving something back to the charity which helped him through a serious illness after he contracted meningitis in December last year.He said that his fundraiser is to thank a ldquowonderful group of people who helped him when the became ill.In particular, Trevor says that he is grateful to the ldquofantastic staff at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald and Saintfield Health Centre who played a vital role in helping save his le.The Meningitis Research Foundation plays a key role in the UK and Ireland by funding vital research, with Trevor keen to see awareness and training of health professionals improved to provide support and information on this health issue.He said said that ahead of his Christmas Eve fundraiser there has been a lot of support and is encouraging others to make their way to the Corner Inn on December .Anyone wishing to make a donation can contact Trevor on  ..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health.
